Sir,

Referring to my letter No.1-28 of the 5th instant in regard to the heating system at the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school, I wish to inform you that I was again called to the school in connection with stoppage of part of the flushing system in the lavatories at this school. The engineer at the school removed some of the smaller water pipes and it was noticed that these pipes, particularly around the unions and elbows, were so badly coated with rust formation that the openings left for the flow of water were very small. The stoppage reported was cleared and the flushing system was again operating but there will no doubt be a recurrence of the trouble.

Going into the wash rooms, it was noticed that when the taps were first opened, the water had a very rusty appearance, clearing only after a quart or two of water had been drained. The whole system is no doubt affected to a certain extent and unless some remedy is applied, it may eventually develop into an expensive undertaking by way of replacements.

I am not sufficiently familiar with plumbing systems to enable me to make any definite suggestions but it occurred to me that if a suitable preparation or solution for softening rust and dissolving rust accumulations could be secured, it might be possible to clean the system at a reasonable cost.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Gullion,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
March 31, 1938.

The engineer at the school removed some of the smaller water pipes and it was noticed that these pipes, particularly around the unions and elbows, were so badly coated with a rust formation that the openings left for the flow of water were very small. The whole system is no doubt affected to a certain extent and unless some remedy is applied, it may eventually develop into an expensive undertaking by way of replacements."
"I am not sufficiently familiar with plumbing systems to enable me to make any definite suggestions but it occurred to me that if a suitable preparation or solution for softening rust and dissolving rust accumulations could be secured, it might be possible to clean the system at a reasonable cost."

Gentlemen:

Re your recent enquiry, re The Blue Quills Indian School, we would advise you that this water has 12 ppm. of iron in same, and this amount of iron would certainly affect the capacity of any Softener in the course of time materially.

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES
Surveys and Engineering Branch.
Dominion Water and Power Bureau.

Calgary, Alta., March 9, 1938.

Re: Blue Quills Indian School Water Supply

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of 2nd instant and yours of 25th ultimo I wish to state that Bell & Morris, of Calgary, have received a report on the iron content of the well water, presumably from the 200 feet level, at the above-named school.

The analysis was performed by Pumps & Softener Limited of London, Ontario, and communicated to Bell & Morris, Calgary, wholesale dealers. Unfortunately the letter did not communicate a complete analysis, viz: of sulphate, etc., which would have been useful. They stated that the iron content was 12 parts per million and that it could be removed by an I.R-30 filter. The retail price quoted was $64.5 f.o.b. London but with Government discounts the price is $64.5 f.o.b. St. Paul, the location of the school.

In an interview with Bell & Morris, yesterday, Mr. Fetterly of this staff requested them to write to the London Company for a complete analysis, if they have it. In order to save time they were requested to send copies to Mr. Mills and the Controller as well as to this office. Consequently this analysis, if available, will arrive in Ottawa about the same time as this letter.

Incidentally, the softener at the school is a Durco.

It was also mentioned to Bell and Morris, while discussing the iron-remover, that the style quoted, viz: the I.R-30, is quoted in the Catalogue as having a capacity of 15 U.S. Gallons per minute or 900 Imperial gallons per hour. Provided the requirements of the school is 4000 gallons the time required to treat the water would be 4½ hours per day. The I.R-30 with 8 gallons per minute would require, at 400 Imperial gallons per hour, 10 hours. The use of the larger unit was questioned by Mr. Fetterly although on afterwards considering the matter, 10 hours appear to be rather long to pump each day and the largest unit might be more in keeping with the water softeners - 2 S.F.B. twinned together, which handle 60,000 grain gallons of Sulphites each while the iron-remover has a capacity of 60,000 wine gallons or 1-P.F.M. iron. This data was given to the London Co. as a reminder when they quoted the I.R-30 Filter.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
The final question to consider is the possibility of all of this machinery as contrasted with cost of a new well, possibly $1300, as intimated in the original letter and wire of 1935. The usefulness of a new well to another depth would have to be considered in contrast to the present one when treated. It appears, however, that a filter, if effective would be less expensive.

A visit to the school before definite plans were made might be advisable.

Enclosed you will find a copy of the Duro Catalogue, Page 32 contains a description of the Filter mentioned above.

I am also enclosing copies of the communications between Bell & Morris and Pumps & Softeners.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) O.H. Hoover,
Engineer-in-Charge.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply, Blue Quills Residential School.

I have your memorandum of the 8th instant with reference to the above, and might say that the only such report was attached to my memorandum of the 17th ultimo.

As regards undertaking to remove the rust from this water, this question was also dealt with in my memorandum of the 17th ultimo from which it will be noted that the installation of a filter for this purpose would cost approximately $642.00. I am, however, still of the same opinion as given in my memorandum of the 17th ultimo, that the expending of an additional $642.00 with $600.00 already expended in a water softener would be a lot of equipment for this well.

In this connection, you will recall that your memorandum of the 2nd ultimo concurred in my suggestion in so far as obtaining the views of Mr. Hoover as to whether it would be better to drive a new well rather than incur the additional filtering expense, and accordingly on the 25th ultimo, Mr. Hoover was written for his opinion in this connection. No reply has yet, however, been received.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
13th April, 1938.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Blue Quills Residential School.

I am in receipt of your memorandum of April 13 with reference to the water supply at the above school.

I agree with you that it would not be advisable to purchase another water softener. At the same time I would appreciate if one of your engineers would visit this school at an early date and carefully consider the advisability of digging another well. Following that visit he could report on the probability of securing water and let me have a reasonably accurate estimate of the cost of a new well. We have not provided any special funds for the purpose but it might be possible to secure the money from the small amount which we have available for unforeseen expenditure, provided your engineer considers that the digging of a new well would be likely to overcome the difficulty that the school management is now experiencing.

Director.
Report
on
Septic Tank and on the Well Conditions
at
Blue Quills (R.C.) Indian School - St. Paul, Alberta
by
P.A. Fetterly, B.Sc., A.M.E.I.C.,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

I. Purpose of Report.
This report is prepared with further reference to a report dated Nov. 8, 1932, regarding the condition of the Septic Tank and also to a telegram received from Ottawa on Dec. 21, 1932, regarding the condition of the wells. The writer visited the location on January 13 and 14.

II. Septic Tank.
A cheque for $500 was received from the Indian Department on 9th ultimo for the purpose of erecting a building 9' x 9' x 7' over the tank and for repairing and changing the location of the motor from the underground concrete chamber to the house provided for it.

H.S. Fraser, of St. Paul, Alta., was entrusted with the construction of the house and I.H. Galloway with the installation of the meter and other electrical work. Estimates were previously obtained and were subsequently closely followed. This portion of the work is now satisfactorily completed.

The septic tank being filled to a depth of 7 feet with unwatered raw sewage which also clogged the outlet pipes, Mr. Fetterly found it necessary, during his visit of January 13, to engage J. Pigeon of St. Paul, to remove it, as Father Angin would not undertake the work with his small staff and no facilities.
Mr. Pignon promised definitely to finish the work but a letter was received from the Principal on January 25th, by which time this office had expected the work was completed, to the effect that he only worked one day and then abandoned it. The Principal was instructed to hire another man whom he mentioned. It is too much to expect Father Angin's staff to do this portion of the work.

The cost to date was as follows:

H.S. Fraser, St. Paul, Carpenter $226.62
This was an extremely reasonable cost.

I.H. Galloway, St. Paul, Electrician. 45.32
This was also very reasonable.

Standard Iron Works, Edmonton 68.40
Repair of motor and fabrication of extensions, etc.

The motor was found when unwound to be in poorer condition than first thought.

Total. $336.34

The first two bills were paid from the $500 advance. The last invoice is in hand but is being held until the bill for removal of sewage is received, which should be within a few days. The total required extra amount will then be requested from Ottawa.

It is suggested that the Department of Indian Affairs send the circular which has been seen at other schools containing instructions that the septic tank be cleaned out every six months. Father Angin states that he has never received a copy.

III. Wells.

Immediately on receipt of the wire dated December 31st, W.E. Gullion, the Indian Agent at Saddle
Lake Agency, in whose district the school is situated, was communicated with. He stated that the driller had again brought in water, at least temporarily and that a visit by the writer was not immediately necessary. A visit was made on January 13 and 14.

A resume of the writer's findings are as follows:

(a) Three wells have been drilled.

Well No. 1.

Drilled 300 feet west of the school in 1930 on the slope of a hill about 20 feet high. This well is 470 feet deep. Four veins of water were found 96', 205', 327', 460'. The first vein contained hard water and the last two fairly soft water. There were 350 feet of water in the well producing 2500 gallons per hour. It is said that the hole became crooked in the last few feet. Casing was lowered to the bottom. Some of this casing was afterwards removed. It was 6", 5" and 4½" in diameter. This well afterwards partially filled with sand and was definitely abandoned.

Well No. 2.

Drilled within five feet of No. 1 in 1930 by the Contractors who built the school, for construction purposes, to the 96 foot vein. This produced very hard water and was not intended for permanent use by the School. It is at present used continuously when no water is available from No. 3, which is now nearly all of the time. It produces 2000 gallons per day. The school requires about 4000 gallons, and consequently must ration the water. They melt snow for soft water. The casing in this well is 6" diameter throughout.
An analysis made January 3, 1933, by the Alberta Provincial Analyst indicated a hardness of 85.68 grains per gallon (St. Barnabas School Onion Lake, Sask., water contains 38 grains).

Well No. 5.

This well was drilled to the 327 foot vein within 50 feet of the School, in August, 1931. The hole is 8 inches diameter with a 6" casing throughout. The hole is straight. Water came up to within 92 feet of the surface, i.e. 235 feet of fairly soft water. All veins of No. 1 were struck at similar depths.

The water pipe is 3" diameter. The Department had to go to the 327 foot vein to get sufficiently soft water. The analyst on January 3, 1933, found it to contain 14 grains per gallon.

(a) Later Activities with Well No. 5.

The driller of Well No. 5, Mr. Frederickson, of St. Paul, Alta., was called in by W.E. Gullion, Indian Agent, to ascertain the reason for cessation of flow, on Nov. 5. He worked at various times until Christmas.

When the well was finished, August 1931, he put 3 feet of average gravel in the casing. During the 14 succeeding months 40 feet of sand, similar to the sample which is being sent under separate cover, apparently came through the gravel into the casing. The sample being sent was gathered in the water and dried for transportation. It must have some silt as 2 hours are required for settling. It is not sand rock. This sand, as will be noticed, is very fine and would go through a 100 mesh screen or even finer. A sand point would not stop it. Any screen which would stop it would probably clog altogether. This sand is being pumped whenever the well is used.
The cylinder is 87 feet from the bottom of the well. The driller removed this sand at the beginning, November 5, by agitation with a baler. He then drilled through the 3 feet of gravel with an 1800 lb. bit. He then placed 10 feet of average gravel and stone into the casing. Apparently he stopped the water nearly altogether. However, after an interval he again drilled through the 10 feet of gravel, his drill becoming stuck twice in the last two feet. He finished by dumping in one pail of gravel. The water was evidently coming intermittently during these times, but the sand was always present in the pumped water, in suspension. In manipulating the pumpseeds and cylinder the rods broke. This is the condition of the well at the present time.

One of three things must have happened when drilling. Either the gravel was pulverized, driven below the end of the casing, or the lower ten feet or so of the casing is broken (6" casing in an 8" hole). However, the writer is assured that the last alternative is not probable.

Mr. Fredrickson, the driller, informed Father Angim that he had sent a report to this office containing a log of the well and an account of his activities but this report has not yet been received.

(b) Solutions of the Problem.

Several solutions were offered, as enumerated below.

The writer returned to Calgary on January 15. He has found since that it is exceedingly difficult to find anybody that has had experience in this sort of well trouble and who has a remedy. After several interviews with engineers, wholesale firms and well drillers, he found that a Mr. Nelson, Instructor at the Technical
Institute, had drilled many wells of this nature, in Northern Alberta. Pending receipt of Mr. Fredrickson's report, he offered a logical solution. This was afterwards corroborated by a former South Dakota driller who lives in Calgary and who has invented a pump for this kind of water trouble in which the leather cup washers are inverted and the water forced through a hollow pump rod.

The various solutions are as follows:

**Father Angin's Solution**

Purchase a 4 ton block and 40 feet of chain to lift out the rods if they break because of sand and to pull the cylinder. The accumulated sand could then be taken out by a baler, hand-operated. This could be done every 10 or 12 months and would occupy 5 or 6 days. He states that his own staff could do this work. However, it would constitute a permanent operation. It would cost about $200 for hand-operation, plus the cost of an engine which undoubtedly would have to be purchased for permanent operation, a total of $600.

**Mr. Fredrickson's Solution**

He would sink another well in the immediate vicinity of No.3, to the same depth (387 feet) at a cost of about $900. This is also favoured to some extent by Mr. Gullion. Mr. Fredrickson does not want to touch the old well at all.

A new well may develop the same trouble as before.

**A solution considered by Mr. Gullion and the Writer**

Use No. 2 (96' deep) with possibly another of the same depth near it and use a Zeolitic Water Softener, to soften the water. This water is very hard (86 grains
per gallon) and a water softener would cost from $1200 to $1500 for 4000 gallons per day. It would be a sure solution of the difficulty. It is to be noted that the capacity of No.2 is 2000 gallons per day as far as proved.

Mr. Nelson's Solution

Repair No.3 in the following manner:-

Remove the Cylinder and pipe. Clean out the sand and gravel to the bottom of the casing - 527 feet. Attach sufficient pipe to lower the cylinder to the bottom of the well. Pump slowly steadily and incessantly for two or three days or more, night and day. The thickness of the water vein at 527', possibly consisting of the fine sand, is not known. It may be 6" or one foot. The pump should never stop. The cylinder should be at the bottom to catch all sand as possibly only the finer sand is carried up at present by the cylinder 67 feet above the bottom. However, this incessant pumping should clear a space beneath and around the bottom of the casing and also for a distance vein itself. This would then act as a reservoir. If enough sand were pumped out it might never trouble the well again.

Blue Quills (R.C.) Indian
School - St. Paul, Alberta.

by P.A. Fetterly, B.S., A.M.E.I.C.
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Wells.

Immediately on receipt of the wire dated
December 21st, W.E. Gullion, the Indian Agent at Sad-
dle Lake Agency, in whose district the school is sit-
uated, was communicated with. He stated that the dril-
ler had again brought in water, at least temporarily and
that a visit by the writer was not immediately necessary.
A visit was made on January 13 and 14.

A resume of the writer's findings are as fol-
lows:-

(a) Three wells have been drilled.

Well No. 1.

Drilled 300 feet west of the school in 1930
on the slope of a hill about 20 feet high. This well is
470 feet deep. Four veins of water were found 96', 205',
327', 460'. The first vein contained hard water and last
two fairly soft water. There were 350 feet of water in
the well producing 2500 gallons per hour. It is said
that the hole became crooked in the last few feet.
Casing was lowered to the bottom. Some of this casing
was afterwards removed. It was 6", 5" and 4½" in dia-
meter. This well afterwards partially filled with sand
and was definitely abandoned.

Well No. 2.

Drilled within five feet of No. 1 in 1930 by
the Contractors who built the school, for construction
purposes to the 96 foot vein. This produced very hard
water and was not intended for permanent use by the School. It is at present used continuously when no water is available from No. 3, which is now nearly all of the time. It produced 2000 gallons per day. The school required about 4000 gallons, and consequently must ration the water. They melt snow for soft water. The casing in this well is 6" diameter throughout.

An analysis made January 3, 1933, by the Alberta Provincial Analyst indicated a hardness of 85.68 grains per gallon (St. Barnabas School Onion Lake, Sask., water contains 58 grains).

Well No. 3.

This well was drilled to the 327 foot vein within 30 feet of the School, in August, 1931. The hole is 8 inches diameter with a 6" casing throughout. The hole is straight. Water came up to within 92 feet of the surface, i.e. 235 feet of fairly soft water. All veins of No. 1 were struck at similar depths.

The water pipe is 5" diameter. The Department had to go to the 327 foot vein to get sufficiently soft water. The analyst on January 3, 1933, found it to contain 14 grains per gallon.

(a) Later Activities with Well No. 3.

The driller of Well No. 3, Mr. Fredrickson, of St. Paul, Alta., was called in by W.E. Gullion, Indian Agent, to ascertain the reason for cessation of flow, on Nov. 3. He worked at various times until Christmas.

When the well was finished, August 1931, he put 3 feet of average gravel in the casing. During the 14 succeeding months 40 feet of sand, similar to the sample which is being sent under separate cover, apparently came through the gravel into the casing. The sample being sent was gathered in the water and dried for transportation.
It must have some silt as 2 hours are required for settling. It is not sand rock. This sand, as will be noticed, is very fine and would go through a 100 mesh screen or even finer. A sand point would not stop it. Any screen which would stop it would probably clog altogether. This sand is being pumped whenever the well is used.

The cylinder is 87 feet from the bottom of the well. The driller removed this sand at the beginning, November 3, by agitation with a baler. He then drilled through the 5 feet of gravel with an 1800 lb. bit. He then placed 10 feet of average gravel and stone into the casing. Apparently he stopped the water nearly altogether. However, after an interval he again drilled through the 10 feet of gravel, his drill becoming stuck twice in the last two feet. He finished by dumping in one pail of gravel. The water was evidently coming intermittently during these times, but the sand was always present in the pumped water, in suspension. In manipulating the pump rods and cylinder the rods broke. This is the condition of the well at the present time.

One of three things must have happened when drilling. Either the gravel was pulverized, driven below the end of the casing, or the lower ten feet or so of the casing is broken (6" casing in an 8" hole). However, the writer is assured that the last alternative is not probable.

Mr. Fredrickson, the driller, informed Father Angin that he had sent a report to this office containing a log of the well and an account of his activities but this report has not yet been received.

(b) Solutions of the Problem

Several solutions were offered, as enumerated below.
The writer returned to Calgary on January 15. He has found since that it is exceedingly difficult to find anybody that has had experience in this sort of well trouble and who has a remedy. After several interviews with engineers, wholesale firms and well drillers, he found that Mr. Nelson, Instructor at the Technical Institute, had drilled many wells of this nature, in Northern Alberta. Pending receipt of Mr. Fredrickson's report, he offered a logical solution. This was afterwards corroborated by a former South Dakota driller who lives in Calgary and who has invented a pump for this kind of water trouble in which the leather cup washers are inverted and the water forced through a hollow pump rod.

The various solutions are as follows:

**Father Angin's Solution**

Purchase a 4 ton block and 40 feet of chain to lift out the rods if they break because of sand and to pull the cylinder. The accumulated sand could then be taken out by a baler, hand-operated. This could be done every 10 or 12 months and would occupy 5 or 6 days. He states that his own staff could do this work. However, it would constitute a permanent operation. It would cost about $200.00 for hand-operation, plus the cost of an engine which undoubtedly would have to be purchased for permanent operation, a total of $600.00.

**Mr. Fredrickson's Solution**

He would sink another well in the immediate vicinity of No. 5, to the same depth (327 feet) at a cost of about $900. This is also favoured to some extent by Mr. Gullion. Mr. Fredrickson does not want to touch the old well at all.

A new well may develop the same trouble as before.
A solution considered by Mr. Gullion and the Writer.

Use No. 2 (96' deep) with possible another of the same depth near it and use a Zeolitic Water Softener, to soften the water. This water is very hard (86 grains per gallon) and a water softener would cost from $1200 to $1500 for 4000 gallons per day. It would be a sure solution of the difficulty. It is to be noted that the capacity of No.2 is 2000 gallons per day as far as proved.

Mr. Nelson's Solution.

Repair No. 3 in the following manner:

Remove the Cylinder and pipe. Clean out the sand and gravel to the bottom of the casing - 327 feet. Attach sufficient pipe to lower the cylinder to the bottom of the well. Pump slowly steadily and incessantly for two or three days or more, night and day. The thickness of the water vein at 327', possibly consisting of the fine sand, is not known. It may be 6" or one foot. The pump should never stop. The cylinder should be at the bottom to catch all sand as possibly only the finer sand is carried up at present by the cylinder 87 feet above the bottom. However, this incessant pumping should clear a space beneath and around the bottom of the casing and also for a distance vein itself. This would then act as a reservoir. If enough sand were pumped out it might never trouble the well again.

Conclusion

This report is prepared pending receipt of Mr. Fredrickson's log and report and possible subsequent consultation with Mr. Nelson.

It is evident from the divergence of opinion and from the various interviews that the solution of the problem is difficult. The only feasible source of water for the school consists of one of the exposed veins and one of
these must be developed.

Considerable consideration of the problem before taking action is warranted because of the cost of experimenting.

A sample of the sand which comes from the well with the water is being sent under separate cover. This sand may or may not consist of the entire content of the vein or the coarser sand may be at the bottom.

Ottawa, February 7th, 1935.

Mr. J.T. Johnston,
The Director,
Dominion Water Power Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re: File 41167 - W.

I have your letter of February 6th in reference to difficulties encountered in drilling for water at the Blue Quills Indian School near St. Paul, Alberta, and sample of sand from No. 3 well.

The difficulty of fine sand and silt coming with the water and plugging the well has been met with at many places in the prairie Provinces, and in other regions. H.E. Simpson, State water geologist of North Dakota states in a recent report that "it is not an exaggeration to say that thousands of holes (in North Dakota) have been abandoned and hundreds of thousands of dollars lost through the inability of the drillers to secure water in ample amounts from fine sand deposits in which the water occurred in abundance. Even after wells have been finished and enough water apparently secured, the life of other thousands of these wells has been brief due to the infiltration of the fine sand, the clogging of the screens, the filling of the pipes, and the cutting out of the valves in the pumps. If the problem of securing this water through proper drilling and finishing of these wells can be solved, it will be not only a great financial saving, but also a great material benefit to the people of the state by reason of better water supplies."

The method proposed by Mr. Nelson, namely cleaning out of the well and pumping sand and water sufficiently long to clear a space around the bottom of the casing, is the one commonly adopted. As much of the material is fine enough to be carried in suspension in the water I doubt whether the method would be successful except temporarily. A method used by the Kelly Well Company, the Layne Canadian and other large well drilling concerns might be successful, but would be very expensive. A large outside casing is put down to the water sand and fine gravel placed between it and the screen at the lower part of the inside smaller casing. The outer casing is then withdrawn and a filling placed around the inner casing. A modification of this scheme by using two small casings with a screen on the inner one and gravel between the two at the water sand might be tried. A very fine screen would be required and it is doubtful whether it would not become plugged.

A sieve analysis of the sand is as follows; probably the sand in place is somewhat coarser;

| Plus 0.1 mm. | 38 |
|--------------|----|
| 0.1/0.05 mm. | 14 |
| Minus 0.05 mm. | 50 per cent |

The sample is, therefore, fine grained. A little of the plus 0.1 mm. portion is retained on a 0.2 mm. sieve. The grains are subangular.
In connection with the plan favoured by Mr. Fetterly, namely using No. 2 well, which seems to be the most feasible scheme, it may be advisable to find out whether there is a screen in the well and if not whether a screen would increase the water supply. This would depend upon the thickness and character of the water sand. If it is proposed to soften the water a fairly complete analysis of the water should be made; some hard waters can be softened by the Zeolite exchange silicate process whereas others cannot. Analyses are made by some of the firms handling water softeners.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd) W.A. Johnston.

I. Introduction.

A letter was sent to the Director, dated April 22nd, 1935, stating that the writer was proceeding to St. Paul immediately to make an inspection of difficulties which had been mentioned in the wire and telephone conversation with Mr. W.E. Gullion, Indian Agent, and Mr. J.E. Fredrickson, driller. These men were interviewed on April 26 and 26.

II. Mr. Fredrickson's Activities.

It was ascertained that the new 3" piping, rods and cylinder had been placed in the well, the bottom of the 6" casing being at the 326 foot level. The water vein being utilized runs from 325 feet to 327 feet, i.e., 4' thick, with the casing one foot from the bottom of the sand vein. A stratum of clay lies under this vein.

Mr. Fredrickson stated that when he started to work the first time, i.e., about November 1, 1932, the accumulation of sand in the 6" casing was 40 feet thick. He, of course, stopped working about December 25. When he began again about April 15, 1933, he found 24 feet of sand, the accumulation of 3½ months. This sand was so dense that he had to drill through it.
instead of simply baling it out. This, of course, all took place in the lower 24 feet of the 6" casing, and occupied about half a day. He then lowered the cylinder and pumped water and mud (please note that it seemed to be mud rather than sand, but was similar to the samples which were obtained by the writer on January 10 and sent to Ottawa), for 2½ hours.

It then stuck solid and the pump stopped because of the resistance at the end of that time. He then removed the 3" piping and cylinder, about 3 hours' work. He then had to drill the sand out again and bail out until the water became fairly clear but not as clear as it was 2 years ago when he first drilled it. Three days were occupied in this one operation. The sand appears to almost actually shoot up to a depth of several feet within a few minutes.

This operation was repeated three times, each time there being 10' or 12' of sand in the casing accumulated within a few hours or less. The last two times he could only pump 15 or 20 minutes, before the cylinder froze. He had to extract pipe, rods and cylinder every time he cleaned it. When he had tried this for three times he decided that it was wasted effort and advised Mr. Gullion, on April 28, to communicate with Calgary office, stating that the "Nelson plan" had proved unsatisfactory.

III. Cause of Troubles

Mr. Fredrickson believes that the trouble is caused by the fact that the lower 20 feet of casing, or a certain length of it has been ruptured by the continuous
drilling and pounding and that the "mud" in the water comes from the clay stratum immediately above the water sand vein as it is much finer than the original water vein sand. This is problematical. He claims that when he finished the well two years ago, he advised that the pump be started immediately and pumping continued until all sand has disappeared from the water. He believes that this was not done and was the cause of the present trouble. He also states that a well should always be pumped immediately after it is finished to clear it and that if this is not done trouble is liable to ensue. Mr. Nelson agrees with this fact.

IV. Fredrickson's Cure

Mr. Fredrickson is of the opinion that a new well should be driven about 50 or 40 feet away from the present well. He claims that under certain conditions he will guarantee a free flowing well, if he be allowed to plan it and to pump until clearing as soon as finished. He states that a well cannot be allowed to stand as it will deteriorate.

He would not place the cylinder at the bottom of the well as in the present experiment. He drilled a well for the St. Paul Flour Mill, two miles to the east, 360 feet deep, and kept it going for a month. This water is rather harder than that of the School well.

He thought of inserting a 5" casing inside the 6" casing, for the full distance with a screen on the bottom but if the 5" casing were ruptured mud would still
enter to the cylinder.

He claims that he cannot clean the well with the baler as the water stays muddy continuously. Mr. Nelson and Mr. Fredrickson agree on the system of continuous pumping and the latter states that this should have been done at the beginning as it cannot be done now because of the nature of the sediment, as explained above, they only being able to pump for a few minutes at each operation before cleaning the cylinder and pipe.

V. Log of Well

The log of the present well, No.5, is not now available, but the log of Well No. 1, drilled by J.G. Douglas, 11706-87th St. Edmonton, in 1929, has been given as follows (this well is 300 ft. west of No. 1 and of the School):

- Yellow Clay 0' - 30'
- Blue Clay 30' - 100' - Very Hard water vein at 98'.
- Hard blue clay 100' - 120'
- Blue Clay and Many Boulders 120' - 198'
- Clay & Gravel 198' - 228' Hard water at 207'
- Sand 228' - 298'
- "Soft water" sand 298' - 330' Softer water at 324' (Clay 2')
- Fine Sand 330' - 360'
- Coarse Sand 360' - 370'
- Fin. Sand 370' - 390'
River Sand 590' - 410'
Sand mud
Quicksand, gravel
and clay 420' - 461' bottom of well,
soft water.

VI. Notes.

A considerable amount of gravel has been placed at different times in the well for straining purposes. This gravel and the sand have been drilled through or pushed down or outwards at various times. It is difficult to estimate the exact or approximate condition of the bottom of the well and 6" casing.

The present pump should deliver 350 to 500 gallons per hour and the present well should produce this amount if in good order. This amount would be sufficient for all school purposes.

VII. Observations.

For the first time the writer has had an opportunity of observing Mr. Fredrickson. He has been drilling wells for 14 years and consequently has a considerable amount of experience in this work. He appears to be quite anxious to obtain water and, in the writer's opinion has done what he could. Mr. Gardner-Smith recommended him in the beginning with apparently good reason after making enquiries.

The writer, together with Mr. Gullion and Father Angin, and afterwards, with Mr. Fredrickson consulted today regarding the matter, and, allowing for
limited knowledge on the part of all but the latter, came to the conclusion that the only solution they could see was to drill another well 20' or 30' to the west, with all of the precautions gained in the experience of drilling No. 3.

While awaiting definite instructions from Ottawa on the matter, Mr. Fredrickson has been instructed to make one more attempt. This consists in beginning with a clear casing as far as may be known, then pour in a few feet of gravel, say 5 or 4 feet, then insert the pump and test the efficiency of the screening. If sand is still found to come through, place one or more feet of gravel and try again. In this way an exact amount of gravel to stop the sand but not too much to stop the water may be found. If this fails then no other method is known to the writer. One considers that the limit for experimentation has been nearly reached in the present well. The cost will soon approximate that for a new well if not stopped. Mr. Fredrickson guarantees a new well under certain conditions which are not difficult, and are principally concerned with the cost.

The water question is more serious to the School than ever because the snow - which has been their principal source of soft water - has disappeared. Laundry conditions are deplorable and the hard water is affecting the water pipes. Father Angin is exceedingly anxious and urged the writer to wire to Ottawa for an immediate answer and authority to proceed.
Mr. Fredrickson's presence on the work increases the cost every day he is there, consequently early instructions are imperative. It is obviously impossible for the writer to be in constant attendance at the School to check up the activities.

Mr. Nelson, on April 28, proposed one last attempt to save the well. This plan was to drill a further 40 feet below the casing, then lower a charge of 4 sticks of dynamite 15' below the casing to produce a cavity into which the sand surrounding the bottom could run, if it will not come up by pumping. This was found to be impossible because the sand runs into the drilled hole as fast as drilled and packs there. To hold it, the casing would have to be driven through the water vein and thus cut off the supply.

VIII. Cost Estimate.

It is estimated that a new well, together with an underground gallery 20 feet long, extending the present one would cost about $1300 or $1400. This would include casing, drilling and extension of the basement. The recently purchased material would be utilized.

IX. Addendum.

The writer has just witnessed the baling of the well. The water obtained in the bailer contains at a rough estimate about 5% of fine sand and mud. This settles in 10 minutes to a muddy appearing opaque water with much sediment on the bottom of the can. The remainder clears fairly well in about 2 or 3 hours indicating that clay is present. A sample of the sediment was obtained and dried. It is similar to that obtained in January.
I. Conclusion.

A perusal of this report, prepared at the School, will convey to the reader all that is known by the writer regarding the well situation. Suggestions have been made as to possible procedure. It is with a great deal of hesitation that one recommends another well as the expense of obtaining water has already been great, but it is the only solution to the writer's knowledge.

P.A. FETTERLY,
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Dated at St. Paul, Alta., April 26, 1935.

(sgd) O.H. Hoover,
Engineer-in-Charge.

Calgary, Alta., June 14, 1935.

Re: Blue Quills Indian School Well Situation.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that Mr. Fetterly of this staff visited the above named School on June 9th to examine Well No. 3 and to prepare the accounts of J.E. Fredrickson and Father Angin for payment. These are attached to another letter of even date.

He found that Well No. 3 is working satisfactorily. Father Angin is satisfied, providing the water is not too hard. The present capacity is limited by the capacity of the pump. This pump is rated at 600 gallons per hour but on test produced about 500 gallons. The well as at present conditioned would probably produce upwards of 1000 gallons per hour if the pump could handle it. Plenty of water is now available for the School.

Mr. Fredrickson, as a last resort, on the advice of Mr. Gullion and on previous suggestion by Mr. Fetterly, exploded two charges of dynamite of three sticks each, at different times; one at 200 feet and the other at 200 feet. The water, presumably from the "200 ft. seam" arose to within 45 feet from the surface of the ground at the time. It was still at that point on June 9th. The cylinder is 100 feet from the surface. The water has been coming since May 20th with no apparent diminution. The School needs 4000 to 5000 gallons per day. There are at present 130 people. If the school filled the number would be 185.

There is no means of knowing whether the well will be a permanent producer. Only time will answer this. At any rate, three quart jars of water were obtained by Mr. Fetterly. He allowed the pump to activate for some time before collecting the water directly from the well. The original sample from this vein indicated 50 grains per gallon of hardness. There is a strong possibility that the present water is too hard for plumbing and boilers. This can only be found on analysis.

I am therefore sending you a sample of the water collected on June 9th. I will send another sample to the University of Alberta for analysis. The third sample will be retained for possible future use of a manufacturer of Water Softeners.

The Director,
Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa.
You will note that a sand sediment is present. This was not noted at the time of collection, although the water was very slightly discoloured.

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant, paragraph 5, I might state that we were very anxious regarding the expense which was being incurred in attempting to clean out the well but could see no other solution except to attempt rehabilitating Well No. 3 as authorized by you and while awaiting authority to begin another well if efforts were useless. Mr. Fredrickson was on the ground with his outfit and continued his attempts. As a result he has now obtained water, although of unknown hardness. The cost has been much less than was anticipated by this office.

As will be noted, no expense has been incurred since May 20, due to Mr. Fredrickson's expressed unwillingness to add to the already high cost of obtaining water. Mr. Fredrickson has been very reasonable throughout.

With regard to the 4th paragraph of the same letter I might explain that the present well is situated in a 6' x 6' concrete "tunnel" extending at right angles for about 30 feet from the boiler room. The top of the tunnel, consisting of concrete is at the surface of the ground. The greater portion of this tunnel is occupied by the pressure tank. The end of the tunnel farthest from the building contains the pump and well No. 3 in a space 4' x 6' x 6'.

It was proposed to extend this space for 60 feet further for the proposed new well in order to get away from the influence of Well No. 3.

In order to save expense it was proposed that the chamber for the new well at the end of the new tunnel 60' from the building would have been 6' x 6' x 6' with a narrow gallery for pipes connecting with the old one to minimize excavation and concrete. The alternative method would be to construct a house above the new well. This was considered to be more expensive than an extended tunnel. This new gallery and tunnel would have been at the same elevation as the original, the top being at the surface of the ground.

Mr. Fetterly is of the opinion that the matter can be left in status quo at present until the well has proved itself or until the necessity for a water softener is evident from analysis of the samples which have been secured.

It is to be acknowledged that the very small
quantity of fine sand in the sample submitted is rather disturbing but this may disappear on continued use of the well, although it may also gradually fill up the pipes below the cylinder or collect in the pressure tanks on settling. The results of this particular difficulty will be found later.

Your obedient servant,

PURPOSE OF REPORT

This report deals finally with the Water Supply at Blue Quills Indian School, St. Paul, Alberta. Letters from this office dated May 30, June 5, 14 and 15, and July 4, the latter containing copies of the chemical analysis, were sent the Director fully covering the well situation.

A final visit was made on July 20 in connection with vouchers.

CONDITION OF WATER SUPPLY

The well was found to be working properly and is producing sufficient water for all purposes. This water is rather hard, as shown by the analysis, but the School Engineer, in the absence of Father Angin, stated that it was "pretty good, although a little hard". A letter from the Director, dated July 17, stated that "no funds were available at the present time for the installation of a water softener and that so long as the water supply remains

The matter of a softener will thus remain in abeyance as long as conditions are as at present.

CONCLUSION

Referring to Mr. MacKenzie's letter of 11th ultimo, File 115-1-5, Ref. 128247 W, last paragraph, there should be no further expenditure at this school for Water Supply.

Mr. Wardle,

Report on
New Well at Blue Quills Indian School
St. Paul, Alberta,

by
P.A. Betterly
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report.

Pursuant to instructions dated May 14, a visit was made to the above named school on May 16, 1936, where a conference was held with J.E. Fredrickson, driller, and Father Allard regarding details of a new well to replace the one now in use.

2. Previous History.

Three wells have been drilled, one at 460 feet to soft water, but the well was never used apparently through immediate non-use; one to 107 feet which was too hard; one at 327 feet which could not be used; while the last attempt, made in about 1935, was to explode a charge in the last-named well at 200 feet in an attempt to use it.

To recapitulate, there are four senses of water:
a. 98' entirely too hard for any use,
b. 200' very hard but used for the past several years through rupturing the casing with dynamite,
c. 327' a softer water which could be used but through apparent misuse at the time of drilling became useless because of sand,
d. 460' a soft water which can not be used because of the mixture of fine sand and mud.

(Note. This recapitulation is from memory as this report is being prepared in the field.) It is the
third seam which Mr. Fredrickson proposes to develop with the proposed new well.

3. Proposals.

The pressure tank is housed in a basement with no superstructure above ground which lies for a distance of 21 feet at right angles to the main building (westward), and 10 feet wide. The pump basement extends a further 11 ft. westward from the end of the tank basement. Thus, the two structures are continuous in every way and extend for 33 feet westward from the main building, with a wall between pierced by a door.

It is proposed to add a further basement 10 feet wide and 8' long to the present pump house which is 6 feet high. The new well would thus be about 7 feet west of the present well.

A plan can be prepared on the writer's return to the office but it is not essential as the structure is simple, consequently the work can go ahead without it if necessary.

Mr. Fredrickson proposes to tap the 327' seam which consists of fairly soft water although a screen may have to be used to keep the sand out. This is not certain yet. He wants to handle the matter according to his best judgment and according to the knowledge gained of the strata through the logs of the other drillers (He did not drill the wells but tried to rehabilitate No.3 well). He is a reliable driller and anxious to make a success of the matter after the failures of other drillers in the past.

He wants to pump immediately after striking water
and to a sufficient length of time to prove the well. He also wishes to test the water for hardness before finally passing on it.

4. Materials on hand and to be purchased.

(a) Pump.

The present pump can be used. It is a Beatty self-oiling Deep-well Head, Page 1429-VM, in No. 4 Catalogue of Beatty Bros. It is a good durable pump. It will have to be disconnected from the present well for a day or two to prove the proposed well, then moved back again to supply the School for a short time till the new well is finished, and then finally moved to the new well. These three changes will cost $30.

(b) Concrete basement.

This will be 10' x 8' x 6' high with 8" walls, and Father Allard, who has had considerable experience with concrete construction, will attend to construction of this structure after the well is finished and will charge us for the cement and labor. It will thus be inexpensive. The cost will be about $100. (The west side of the present well basement consists of brick). To be built after well is proved.

(c) Casing.

A total length of 327 feet of 5" inserted casing will be needed and it will have to be on the site before drilling is commenced according to Mr. Fredrickson. At $90.00 wholesale the total cost will be $322.10. Mr. Fredrickson can supply this material wholesale if allowed to do so.

(d) Well Pans.

There are at present on the ground 8-20 foot lengths of 3" plugged and waxed pipe, available for use. There are also 60' in the present well. A further length of 40 feet of 3" p & r pipe will then be needed, or a total length of 260 feet. Thus 40 feet at $92.51 per hundred feet will cost $37.00.

(e) Rods.

There are 94 feet of 1-3/8" octagonal rods on the site and 60 feet more in the present well. Thus, 106 feet more are needed at a cost of $5 per foot or a total cost of $37.10.

(f) Working Barrel.

There is a new 36" x 2½" working barrel at the
school and purchased by the school a year ago in an attempt to rehabilitate the present well. The plunger was used and is not likely to be in good condition. A new plunger will cost about $20.

(g) Screen

A screen may or may not be needed depending on quality of sand. Its length depends on the depth of sand water stratum. The length will probably be 5' to 7' but the cost per foot is not available at present (in the field).

(h) Cost of Drilling.

Mr. Fredrickson's price for drilling will be $1.75 per foot for the first 180 feet and $2.00 per foot thereafter, that is, to 327 feet. The total cost will therefore be as follows:

| Feet     | Cost   |
|----------|--------|
| 180 feet | $315.00|
| 147 "    | $294.00|

Total cost of drilling $609.00

The exact footage may vary slightly.

5. Recapitulation of Cost.

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| Pump (shifting)               | $30.00 |
| Concrete basement             | $100.00|
| Casing, 6 inserted wholesale  | $322.10|
| Well pipe, 13" p & r.         | $37.00 |
| Rods                          | $37.10 |
| Plunger for working barrel    | $20.00 |
| Screen                        | ?      |
| Drilling 327'                 | $609.00|

Total $1155.20

Add 10% for contingencies $155.00

Total estimate $1310.20

6. Time Element.

There are two reasons for immediate action:
(a) Condition of the whole plumbing system.

The tubes of the boilers were examined superficially and are obviously in a bad state. A bill for $100 was incurred a short time ago in repairing the back end and it is not known when any portion of the $15,000 pumping system of the school may fail. The hard water in present use is very bad on the system and works fast in disintegrating the material. For instance, one result to be feared is that the expected soft water of the proposed new well may dissolve any scale already located inside the pipes and expose the material to new disintegration. This is merely given as an illustration of the possible extent of damage to the inside of the boiler pipes, pressure tank, conducting pipes, radiators, etc.

The writer performed ablutions in water too thick to see through, of a reddish brown colour. (Descriptions and analyses have already been reported).

It is obvious that, when the boiler pipes burst some time ago, that other results will probably follow soon.

Thus for this reason alone haste is necessary.

(b) Mr. Fredrickson's Movements.

He stated that he would be in St. Paul until not later than May 30. He is then moving to another part of the province to do some C.P.R. work. He will be busy until that date at St. Paul but couldn't wait longer. After that date he would have to be brought back at a certain cost.

He is a reliable man with good reputation for conscientious work and in fact is the only active driller known to the writer in the north country.
For these two reasons I would recommend that instructions be issued for immediate beginning of the work, i.e., within the next ten days.

7. Mr. Fredrickson's Guarantee

He guarantees sufficient water to supply school if he is allowed to carry out activities according to his own ideas after the drilling is done; e.g., pumping continuously for a time at the expense of the Department, and other minor matters. He is ready to accept half the cost of drilling plus cost of moving the pump three times ($30.00), with the balance at the end of 12 months, as an actual fact it is supposed by the writer that the whole cost will be paid in a reasonable time after finishing the well. He also wished to have the water analysed although he believes the 327' seam will be suitable.

P.A. Fitterly
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

St. Paul, Alberta, May 17, 1938.

Dear Sir;

In compliance with your request, I inspected the boilers at the blue Quill's Indian Residential School, St Paul, Alberta.

I found that one of these boilers (A)9556 was leaking in the firebox, at the tubes, and at the stay bolts of the lower tube sheet, also the lower rows of stays of side sheets in firebox, four rows high from firegrate. I had all the tubes in firebox expanded, and these stood the water test of 45 lbs., without undue leakage, should these give trouble when boiler is fired up; it would mean that these tubes would require to be renewed, owing to the ends having been overheated, thereby losing their tensile strength.

The covering will require to be removed from throat sheet and outer casing side sheets to permit of stays being tightened, it looks to me as though the tube ends and stays were cooled off suddenly, say by water being thrown into firebox and striking them, when there was a hot fire on grates, rather than by shortness of water in boiler, my reason for this is, that the crown sheet and upper rows of stays, in side sheets, do not show any sign of being damaged, which naturally they would have shown a shortness of water in boiler, at the time the damage occurred, also the other end of tubes would have shown leakages as well.

I understand that there was no regular fireman on the premises at the time the accident to boiler took place, and I could not get any authentic account of the occurrence.

At time of my visit the general appearance of the boiler room gave the impression that there was no one giving it much attention, the floor was in a more or less littered condition, with coal and ashes lying around in odd places, the main sewer was
choked, so we had to depend on the small auxiliary opening when emptying the boilers. I was informed that sometimes during the winter this sewer freezes up, and does not open up again till towards the end of July or sometimes in August; this could be remedied somewhat by installing an electric pump, and making a sump in the floor.

I was informed that the return piping gave trouble last winter, rusted away, when renewing them the level of the piping was lowered, at the present level, a non-return valve is required, this to be installed in return line to each boiler, with the present stop valve, that is in line between it and the boiler, there is also a cross connecting pipe running between the two boilers, this takes care of return water from heater for heating water for the building, this pipe should be connected to main return pipes, on the building side of non-return valves, that is with non-return and stop valves between connection & boilers, this would prevent the water from moving from one boiler to the other should there be any variance of the pressures in the boilers from whatever cause.

The fire grates to be moved from place, plates freed from rust and a good boiler paint used to paint the plates, this should be done every year on all three boilers, to counteract any tendency of plates corroding.

One tube requires to be renewed on Boiler (A)9557, this tube gave out during test, a pit hole developed on the underside of tube had eaten through.

On looking over the domestic water supply installation for building, I found that there was considerable leakage of water past pump rod and packing gland, requires new packing in stuffing box, I could not locate any safety valve on piping from pump to storage tank, there should be one on system to take care of overpressure, so that there is less likelihood of the tank or piping giving out, at present the only devise taking care of this is the electric stopping and starting switch for the electric motor of pump.

It would be advisable in the summer months that certain routine work be carried out, which cannot very well be done when the heating system is in operation, such as repairs to pipe lines, grinding in or
or replacing valves on boilers, water lines, steam lines throughout the building, there is also the pump to be attended to, as well as the lighting system. I would mention here that to comply with the boilers Act and regulations, a certificated man is required to look after the high pressure boiler when it is in use; this man should also be able to undertake such repairs as I have mentioned above.

The domestic water supply to buildings appears to be somewhat troublesome to the piping; it looks as though there is some iron in it; it comes out of the pipes fairly red if the valve has been closed for any length of time; there is not much scale forming material init judging from the inside of boilers, where it leaves a slight deposit of reddish sludge; it has a tendency to cause a pitting action on the underside of tubes and the lower parts of the interior of boilers.

A separate blow down valve should be installed for the heating boilers.

Yours very truly,

H.G. Alexander,
Boiler Inspector.

In accordance with instructions received from Mr. Inspector Schmidt by letter No. 407-11A of the 9th instant as per reference your letter No. 118-1-5 of August 3rd addressed to him, I beg to submit herewith in triplicate, Form 372 containing list of material required to repair the boilers; also the approximate number of hours of labor and cost of same.

Being uncertain as to the exact condition of the tubes, I made arrangements to have these as well as the other requirements checked by Mr. Jeffery Dubois, engineer, on the 13th. One of the tubes was taken out and a light inserted. Most of the tubes were found to be badly pitted from corrosion and it is considered that they would not stand steam pressure for any length of time. For your information, I am forwarding to the Department a parcel containing a portion of one of the tubes taken out of the boiler at the school. If the Department approves, Mr. Jeffery Dubois of St. Paul, Alta., offers to do the necessary repair work at the rate of sixty cents per hour. Mr. Alexander informed me that Mr. Dubois is a very capable engineer and he has the necessary working equipment on hand.

Sir,

With reference to the new well at the above-named school I am enclosing a telegram received this morning from J.E. Fredericksen, driller. As a consequence I immediately phoned him for the purpose of determining definitely why it was necessary to insert a second string of casing, (4\(\frac{1}{4}\)" as suggested in the wire, into the present 5" casing.

Mr. Fredericksen explained that the 5 inch casing which is at present in the well will very shortly penetrate a sand formation and by experience of the last few days drilling he is convinced that it would be practically impossible to shut off the water at the ninety five and two hundred foot levels if the 5 inch casing was carried further and into this sand streak. With great difficulty the water at ninety five and two hundred foot levels has now been completely shut off and as the purpose of the well is to shut off the flow of the extremely hard water from two seams it was decided to allow Mr. Fredericksen to run a second and new string of 4\(\frac{1}{4}\) inch casing and not to further disturb the present 5 inch string which is at the present time completely sealing off the water veins as above mentioned. This will increase the cost of the well to the extent of the cost of additional casing but under the circumstances and if the softer water is obtained in the lower veins the additional cost will be wholly justified.

This unforeseen expenditure could not be avoided and is hereby recommended for approval.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) O.H. Hoover.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter and report on the Blue Quills Residential School received from Agent W. E. Gullion, Saddle Lake Agency.

As regards the equipment asked for, I strongly recommend that same be granted: Tailor's sewing machines are very much needed, as at present the work in the sewing room is being considerably delayed because stitching on heavy materials cannot be done on ordinary sewing machines.

A power mangle is also a necessity at this School.

As regards a suitable building and equipment for manual training purposes, mentioned in the Agent's report, I beg to say that an extra large garage attached to the boiler room of the main building has just been completed: A carpenter's work-bench is being installed at one end of this building, where the boys will be taught general farm carpentry by the school carpenter-labourer. A mechanic's work-bench has been installed in the boiler room, and the older boys are called upon to assist the engineer-mechanic when repair work is done.

I find, however, that the outfits of tools, both carpenter's and Mechanic's, are very limited, and have suggested that a requisition be made for a few more of these.

Sir:

I beg to report that when at the Blue Quills Residential School, Saddle Lake Agency, last week, I noticed that the stench from the septic tank, which is located a few feet from the South-west front corner of the main building, was terrible, and could be smelt all through the house. I was told this septic tank had been cleaned out a short time ago, but that notwithstanding this, the disagreeable odour still prevails, and when the wind is from the West it is impossible to keep windows open.

I note from the files in this office that this matter was looked into in the year 1935 when Mr. D. B. Menzies, Provincial Sanitary Engineer, made a report on same, in which he made three suggestions, one of which (No. 3) was carried out, on instructions received from the Department under date of September 21st, 1935, File No. 118-1-5. As Mr. Menzies' report was forwarded to the Department but no copy kept at this office, I have no idea what the other two suggestions he made, are.

Something will have to be done in the matter before another summer comes along. I cannot understand the idea of placing a septic tank so near a building when there is lots of land and space surrounding it.

I beg to ask that a copy of Mr. Menzies' report, mentioned above, be sent me for my file. After perusing same and going over the ground, I may have a suggestion to offer.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Dept. of Mines & Res.,

Final Report

on

Water Supply at Blue Quills Indian School

by P.A. Setterly,
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report.

This is the final report on new well for Blue Quills Indian School. The original report, dated May 17, 1938, contained estimates and recommendations.

The well is now completed. A copy of a letter was received from Rev. H. Balter, dated January 4, 1939, to C.P. Schmidt, Inspector for Indian Agencies for Alberta, containing an extract, the translation of which reads as follows:

"We profit of this occasion to inform you that the new well obtained from the Department is completed and is at the present time supplying an abundance of soft water. As it is, it can be used for washing clothes without the necessity of adding any ingredient. It is a real blessing for the house."

This would seem to indicate that the new well is a success.

2. Composition of Water

A sample was obtained when the seam was first penetrated which, when analyzed by the Calgary City Chemist, was found to contain a considerable amount of salts but no iron. This discovery provided a sense of anxiety until a new sample was
obtained recently after the well was cleared. This new sample has not yet been analysed but the portion of Rev. L. Balter's letter given above would appear to settle the question even without a further analysis. The new sample is now in the office and will be sent to the Provincial Analyst for analysis. The yield is apparently also very satisfactory.

3. J.E. Frederickson's activities.

It should be mentioned at this point that the driller, Mr. Frederickson is to be highly commended for the able and conscientious manner in which he has carried out his duties, particularly as it was impracticable for the Inspecting Engineer to be present except for one brief visit, and that when only the hole was first drilled. This 227 foot seam was apparently passed in former drillings but he was certain that he could develop it.

4. Cost of Well.

The total cost of the well to date is as follows:

| Description                                      | Amount   |
|--------------------------------------------------|----------|
| Western Supplies Ltd., Edmonton, 5" well casing  | $326.05  |
| J.E. Frederickson, driller, drilling well         | $609.00  |
| Western Supplies Ltd., Edmonton 4½" casing       | $262.80  |
| Hayward Lumber Company, St. Paul, Lumber &c.     | $134.10  |
| Beatty Bros. Ltd., Edmonton, Octagonal wood rods, etc. | $200.81  |
| Crane Ltd., Calgary well screen                  | $100.75  |
| J.E. Frederickson's final invoice (attached)     | $246.88  |

Total: $1929.39

It is true that this amount exceeds that mentioned in
your letter of Nov.5,1938, ($1700) but several unexpected factors entered into the construction. The 4" casing, costing $262.80 was entirely unexpended and unusual but it was necessary to preserve the well. It was of course placed inside the 5" casing which had to be left in position. Again, the pump had to be changed four times, making necessary an extra expenditure of $20 ($50 less $30) in Mr. Fredericksen's current invoice, attached and not yet paid. Another extra expense was $80 for cleaning out the well and putting in the well screen, as the sand was so fine and the delay of obtaining the well screen was so great, owing to the fact that the necessity for the well screen and its design could not be foretold until the sand was sampled and sent to the manufacturers in Illinois for analysis, and the basement built, that the well partially filled up because of the fineness of the sand and had to be cleaned out again. There was also unavoidable delay in obtaining the screen. All this time, several weeks, the drill outfit stood over the well and its use elsewhere lost. The cost of the well screen itself, $100.75, was partially unexpected. This the total unexpected, and unforeseeable expense amounts to $463.55.

As a probable compensation, it appears that the Duro Water Softener, costing $680 plus $55.15 for fittings - valves, pipe, etc., purchased and installed in November, 1939, and which has not been used for two years or more, will not now be necessary as the water is reported as soft. If this be the case, it can now be released for use in another school. Mr. Schmidt recently mentioned that the water of St. Paul
Indian school, Blood Indian reserve, has become hard and may require treatment.

Another matter needing attention is the 5" casing originally purchased but not used in the well for reasons mentioned in a previous report. These are 84 feet of this casing left on the ground. The cost was $98.50 per 100 feet. This is worth $82.74. It is supposed that the invoice of Western Supplies Ltd., Edmonton, from whom it was purchased, has been paid. This casing could not be returned before payment of the invoice as it was not known until the well was completed whether it would be needed.

If the casing be now returned, and it is understood that the Company will do so, less freight, the Indian Affairs Branch will lose the amount to the Receiver General.

Regarding the disposal of this 5" casing Mr. Fredericksen was unofficially contacted and he stated that he was prepared to pay $50.00 for the pipe to be deducted from his latest invoice, now attached.

Providing the water softener will be used in another school the actual cost will be lessened to a considerable extent.

6. Observations on Construction

It is true that the total expenditure exceeds the proposed amount, but several factors enter into the consideration of the matter. This is the fourth well drilled at this school, although the first dealt with by the writer. One was over 400' deep. Another was over 300 feet, another was 90 feet. Its completion has caused a great deal of anxiety and labour and the conclusion may be considered as fortunate. If this well had not been a success the solution of the problem for the school would have been very difficult. In this connection the Sacred Heart School situation is brought to mind. In construction above ground most of the contingencies may be foretold but in a case like this
where so many attempts had been made, all underground and unsuccessful, a previous exact estimate is impossible. Paragraph (5) shows this condition clearly. The main observation is that it appears to be a success. In addition, the Water Softener appears to be available for another school. Another difficulty was in having a constant supply of water for the school during construction where the wells were only seven feet apart. This entailed extra delay and consequent expense which may not easily be anticipated.

7. Recommendation.

It is recommended that the enclosed invoice of J.M. Fredericksen for construction of basement, etc., be paid to a total of $246.78 or, if his offer of $50.00 for the 84 feet of 5" casing be accepted, for $196.78.

The item of $90 for basement was an agreed contract price for complete basement, excavation back-filling, including labour only, and was reasonable as an attempt made at the time of the visit to have it done by hired labour would have cost $150 for this item alone.

Mr. Fredericksen would gladly receive the cheque as soon as possible, as he has already disposed of a considerable portion of the amount from his personal funds.

P.A. Fetterly

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing report of analysis on sample of water received from you and have expressed results in parts per million and in grains per gallon.

You will note a water of medium hardness and containing a considerable amount of sodium carbonate and sodium sulphate. I presume that the Duro softener is of the Zeolite type and should remove all the hardness from this water.

The scale formed from above water would be soft, there being no permanent hardness present. A soft water with no hardness would be much more satisfactory for domestic supply, there being no scale deposited in boilers and considerable saving on soap. While the water is not excessively hard - 9.87 grains - I would consider that the expense involved would be justified, as you have a softener in stock.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Blue Quills Indian School and St. Paul's Indian School.

By reference to our memorandum of January 19th last, it will be noted that as satisfactory results had been obtained at the Blue Quills Indian School from a new well that had been drilled, the suggestion was made that the Indian Affairs Branch give consideration to transferring the Duro Water Softener from the Blue Quills Indian School to some other point where it might be needed such as the St. Paul Indian School as suggested by Mr. Schmidt. Your memorandum of February 3rd last indicated that this matter was receiving the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Under date of the 12th ultimo, we received a letter from Mr. Hoover advising that samples of the water in the well at the Blue Quills School had been analyzed and while the results of such analysis had been found to be reasonably satisfactory, Mr. Hoover was having a second sample tested. Copies of the analysis as well as the report of the Director of Industrial Laboratories at Edmonton covering the first test made are attached.

We are now in receipt of a further letter from Mr. Hoover in which he advises that the second analysis indicated no iron present, and that the sample when tested with a quantity of Zeolite gave results indicating that the Zeolite had removed about 70% of the salts present. The analyst who made the test states that this would cause the water to be quite sufficiently soft for all purposes for which it is intended to be used.

Under the circumstances, it is now recommended that the Duro Water Softener which is now at Blue Quills Indian Residential School be removed to St. Paul's Indian School, Cardston.

Mr. Hoover advises that if this Softener is moved, a representative of his office should be present at Blue Quills School during removal. It appears that Mr. Hoover expects to have Mr. Fetterly at Edmonton about the end of the present month. If we could be advised regarding final decision in connection with removal of this Water Softener shortly, then instructions will be issued so that Mr. Fetterly can supervise the shipment of this Softener from Blue Quills School to St. Paul's School.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I wish to inform you that several leaks have developed in the roof of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school and repairs to the roof will be necessary in order to prevent damage to the plaster inside of the building. Several spots were pointed out to me and it was noticed that there were three patches of plaster in the chapel ceiling that appeared to be loose. Small spots are noticeable in both dormitories and there are leakages around several of the pipes. There is also considerable leakage through the ceiling of the kitchen. The plaster in one corner of the laundry is becoming loose and the ceiling is rather badly cracked.

With the exception of the corner of the laundry and discoloration of plaster in spots where water has seeped through, the damage so far is slight. In order to remedy the cause however, I am of the opinion that it would be necessary to treat the whole roof. It is a hard matter to locate the exact source of the leakages and no doubt there are minute cracks in the roofing composition at various points over the entire roof.

The school could furnish some of the labor but in order to have the work properly done, it should be supervised by a man who has had practical experience in roofing and plaster work. The cost would probably be about $300.00.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

With this in view, the Reverend Principal took up with Messrs. H. Kelly & Company, Limited, Edmonton, the matter of cost of new showers and fixtures and also allowances, in the event of a trade-in, of the used bath tubs and basins at the school. Following is a list of estimated requirements:

Sir:

Re request and suggestion made by the Principal of the Blue Quills Residential School that certain alterations be made in the boys' section -- bath-room and wash-room -- viz.,

(a) Removal of two double rows (7 and 6 double) fixed individual wash basins in the boys' wash-room in the basement, and replacing same with a flowing water system, i.e., long pipes with taps only and draining trough, having a drain-pipe under each tap. The removal of these fixed double rows of individual basins will give sufficient room to install (b);

(b) Installation of five shower baths;

(c) That the five bath tubs in the bath-room adjoining the boys' dormitory be removed. This would provide room for ten (10) extra beds;

the reason for suggesting the changes being that it is found quite difficult to clean, scald and disinfect these bath tubs and wash basins after each individual has used them, and there being many pupils suffering from scabies or impetigo (scabs), and it is believed that the flowing water for washing, and shower baths would greatly help combat this serious and no doubt communicable trouble amongst the pupils, which is always very acute and wide-spread amongst them -- more so on their return to school after the summer holidays.

When discussing the matter with the Principal of the School and yourself last week, I understood you to say that quotations had been obtained for the cost of new material and labour required to make the changes, and that the plumber had made an offer for the bath tubs and wash basins which are to be removed; also, that this information had been forwarded for the Department's information and decision: Apparently this was forwarded direct to Ottawa, as I do not find any trace of it here. I believe it should have been sent through this office, or at least a copy sent here. If my interpretation of Department's Circular No. C. 154 dated May 17th, 1937, is correct: (Ref. No. 1, Buildings, School, "including all new projects for repairs").

Will you please send me, by first mail, copies of all correspondence, quotations, lists of new material required, &c., pertaining to this matter? I am forwarding a copy of this letter to the Department, asking them to withhold their decision on the matter pending receipt of my report, which I will forward upon receipt from you of the information asked for above. My reason for doing so is that -- as I said to you when at the school -- we can make use of the individual wash basins at another school where we have no such equipment, and I would not consider selling or trading them to an outsider at a sacrifice price.

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Yours truly,

Sir,

I wish to inform you that I am forwarding to you by this mail a parcel containing a worn bearing from the pump in the septic tank at the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school. The bearing is marked "Hess Bright" 6400 SKF GDS and has six balls.

Upon being advised that the pump in the tank was out of order yesterday, I went to the school. The pump head had been removed and the parts were being taken up. The end of the shaft, an eight foot length of 1½" pipe, two lock washers and one side of the pump head were damaged by corrosion. The shaft and pump head can be repaired at St. Paul and an 8 ft. length of suitable pipe can also be obtained there.

In order to have the pump repaired and the damaged pipe replaced as soon as possible, I advised them to have this work done at once. The pump can then be used temporarily by hand, in case of emergency. The bearing which I am sending cannot be obtained here. The maker's name is not on the pump but I believe that Messrs. Bell and Morris of Calgary handle them. The number on the pump head is G245-200.

The two lock washers required are for 1½" shaft, the washers being ½" in thickness and 4" across.

Your obedient servant,
