SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA.
August 31st, 1939.

Sir:

I wish to inform you that several leaks have developed in the roof of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school and repairs to the roof will be necessary in order to prevent damage to the plaster inside of the building. Several spots were pointed out to me and it was noticed that there were three patches of plaster in the chapel ceiling that appeared to be loose. Small spots are noticeable in both dormitories and there are leakages around several of the pipes. There is also considerable leakage through the ceiling of the kitchen. The plaster in one corner of the laundry is becoming loose and the ceiling is rather badly cracked.

With the exception of the corner of the laundry and discoloration of plaster in spots where water has seeped through, the damage so far is slight. In order to remedy the cause however, I am of the opinion that it would be necessary to treat the whole roof. It is a hard matter to locate the exact source of the leakages and no doubt there are minute cracks in the roofing composition at various points over the entire roof.

The school could furnish some of the labor but in order to have the work properly done, it should be supervised by a man who has had practical experience in roofing and plaster work. The cost would probably be about $300.00.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Gullion
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

Several times in the past, the Church authorities in visiting our school have suggested the advisability of separating the big boys from the small ones, especially in the recreation hall and in the dormitory. Furthermore, our class rooms are somewhat crowded and we need badly a manual training room.

Therefore with the advice of our Provincial, Rev. Father H. Reuther O.M.I., I am writing you to ask your permission to begin the construction of an addition to our school. In putting a Skylight on the roof of the laundry the proposed addition can be put against the laundry thus the heating of the new building will be easy.

Sir,

Re; Proposed Addition to Blue Quill's Residential School Saddle Lake Agency.

Reference my letter of the 6th instant written in a hurry that evening at Blue Quill's school so that it could be air-mailed at Edmonton next day by Mr. Doucet who was returning there next day, I beg to report further as follows:

When at Blue Quill's school last March, Rev. L. Balter the Principal and Rev. R.F. Pratt, assistant Principal and bursar mentioned in conversation that they were considering building an addition to the school but that no decision had been reached in the matter.

When at the school on the 6th instant Rev. Fr. Pratt in conversation stated they had decided to build, that they had some of the material purchased and that he expected to start excavating next week June 9th-14th. Rev. L. Balter, the Principal, being in Edmonton to attend a Council meeting of the Oblates, and Fr. Pratt being unable to say whether the matter had been referred to the Department. I took it upon myself and phoned Rev. M. Rouxier, the Provincial of the Oblates to ask him whether the Department had been informed. His reply was in the negative and stated he had asked the Principal to do so. On his return that evening, June 6th, I asked Rev. Balter the Principal if he had written to the Department, his reply being also in the negative. I suggested that he do so and also send a plan or sketch and specifications. He agreed to do so saying he would mail them next day. The Department have no doubt received same by now.

The present building faces South. The new addition will be along the East wall of the North section of this, or in other words the outside wall of the laundry, power room "lighting plant room" and garage will be used as the West wall of the addition, or again, three (3) new walls only will have to be built when constructing the 1st story of the proposed new addition. This will mean that the windows in the laundry and power rooms will be closed or blinded. To light these rooms, laundry and power room which are one story only, it is proposed to put sky lights or cupolas or windows on the flat roof.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
What material will be used in the construction of this addition has apparently not been decided upon. The following was mentioned to me - the foundation will be concrete and the lower 4 or 5 feet of the wall concrete also, to serve as a wainscoting; the upper part of the wall will be frame - the inside either stucco or brick veneer. This has not been decided. The roof will be rubberized roofing (not tar or gravel). Floors - cement was mentioned for recreation room and work shop. Heating, steam from boilers, system now in use. Water, connected with present system pressure tank; Fire protection. Lighting, windows to be horizontal.

The North end to have an upper story to be used as a dormitory for the older boys.

This addition will fill a long felt want in view of the fact that this school have many more pupils in attendance over the quota for which the original building was built.

For the information of the Department please I understand the matter has not been taken up with the Indian Agent's office.

Yours truly,

G.F. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir,

re Blue Quill's Residential School.

For your information I would state that the unit is of the Kelvinator Type with the compressor and engine on the outside of the refrigerator, it did not appear to be in any too good shape and I was informed it started giving trouble on Friday June 13th last and was certainly not working properly when I saw it on Saturday June 21st.

Father Pratt informed me that it would cost in the neighborhood of $60.00 to have a man out from Edmonton—Ryan Bros—to put the unit in order. Saturday morning he requested me to wire the department for this authority however I am air mailing instead and if the department authorize this expenditure, I would ask to be informed by wire.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of September 1941.

SCHOOLS

Both Blue Quills School and the Edmonton School opened on the 22nd of Sept., after the ban was lifted in connection with polio. Children returned to both schools on Sept. 23rd. A fair response resulted at the present there being 16 absent from Blue Quills School, most of them away with their parents threshing on the out side. Some six children are absent from the Edmonton School. A few new recruits went to school but up to the time of writing have not received their applications. Called at the Blue Quills School once during the month before the school opened to inspect bake oven that the repairs are being paid for by the department. The progress of the building of the addition to this school is very slow and it would appear very doubtful that it will be finished this year. It would appear that the school undertook just about a little more than they can manage.

Dear Sir:

Following our telephone conversation of some few days ago, we have pleasure in submitting for your approval, the following tender to supply and install Frigidaire automatic refrigeration in the Blue Quill Indian School at St. Paul.

The present box in the school is now approximately 5 x 8 x 9, inside measurements, and appears to be insulated with three inches of cork board. The equipment required to cool this box would be -

1 - Model WF-250, 1/2 h.p. Frigidaire water-cooled condensing unit.
1 - Model WX-1466 Cooling Coil, complete with thermostatic expansion valve.
1 - Model PX-22 Ice-Making Frigidaire cooling coil, complete with thermostatic expansion valve. Having a capacity to freeze 19 lbs. of ice, or 156 tubes at one freezing, and is equipped with 6 trays. We have figured this to handle three complete freezings of ice per day.

We are proposing to use a water-cooled condensing unit, owing to the fact that the room the compressor would have to sit in is closed at all times and ventilation is rather poor; and, as this room is used as a storeroom, an air-cooled unit would only have a tendency to heat this room up.

Price of the above-mentioned equipment, completely installed, f.o.b. Edmonton, including the trade-in of the old equipment presently installed, would be $480.00 (previously quoted $500.00)

For your information, we are enclosing, herewith, illustrative cuts of the equipment.

The above equipment is guaranteed for one year against defective parts and workmanship, during which time you are entitled to free service should it be required.

Should there be any further information you require, we would be only too pleased to be of assistance to you.

Thanking you for a favorable consideration of this tender, we remain,

Yours very truly,

Sir,

Re: Proposed Addition to Blue Quill's Residential School Saddle Lake Agency.

Reference my letter of the 6th instant written in a hurry that evening at Blue Quill's school so that it could be air-mailed at Edmonton next day by Mr. Doucet who was returning there next day, I beg to report further as follows:

When at Blue Quill's school last March, Rev. L. Balter the Principal and Rev. R.F. Pratt, assistant Principal and bursar mentioned in conversation that they were considering building an addition to the school but that no decision had been reached in the matter.

When at the school on the 6th instant Rev. Fr. Pratt in conversation stated they had decided to build, that they had some of the material purchased and that he expected to start excavating next week June 9th-14th. Rev. L. Balter, the Principal, being in Edmonton to attend a Council meeting of the Oblates and Fr. Pratt being unable to say whether the matter had been referred to the Department. I took it upon myself and phoned Rev. M. Routhier, the Provincial of the Oblates to ask him whether the Department had been informed. His reply was in the negative and stated he had asked the Principal to do so.

On his return that evening, June 6th, I asked Rev. Balter the Principal if he had written to the Department; his reply being also in the negative. I suggested that he do so and also send a plan or sketch and specifications. He agreed to do so saying he would mail them next day. The Department have no doubt received same by now.

The present building faces South. The new addition will be along the East wall of the North section of this, or in other words the outside wall of the laundry, power room "lighting plant room" and garage will be used as the West wall of the addition; or again, three (3) new walls only will have to be built when constructing the 1st story of the proposed new addition. This will mean that the windows of the laundry and power rooms will be closed or blinded. To light these rooms, laundry and power room which are one story only, it is proposed to put sky lights or cupolas or windows on the flat roof.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.
What material will be used in the construction of this addition has apparently not been decided upon. The following was mentioned to me - the foundation will be concrete and the lower 4 or 5 feet of the wall concrete also, to serve as a wainscoting; the upper part of the wall will be frame - the inside either stucco or brick veneer. This has not been decided. The roof will be rubberized roofing (not tar or gravel). Floors - cement was mentioned for recreation room and work shop. Heating, steam from boilers, system now in use. Water, connected with present system pressure tank. Fire protection. Lighting, windows to be horizontal.

The North end to have an upper story to be used as a dormitory for the older boys.

This addition will fill a long felt want in view of the fact that this school have many more pupils in attendance over the quota for which the original building was built.

For the information of the Department please I understand the matter has not been taken up with the Indian Agent's office.

Re: Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
Saddle Lake Agency.

In further reference to your memorandum of December 21st last enclosing a copy of Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of the 7th idem regarding drainage from the school and the condition of the septic tank, an inspection was made by Mr. Cornish on May 21st and 22nd last and the following extract from his report is quoted hereunder:

(1) Flooding of boiler room

"The soft water cistern is a concrete tank of approximately 4000 gallons capacity built under the floor of the laundry and fed by runoff from the school roofs through the rainwater pipes. The cistern overflow drain and the drain from the boilerroom floor sump join outside the building and discharge through a 6" V.T. pipe into a slough north of the school. A floor drain from the garage in the building also runs into this line. The invert of the overflow at the cistern is 2.5 feet higher than the boiler room floor and the invert of the drain at the slough is 3.7 feet lower than the boiler room floor.

"The serious flooding of the boiler room (and of the well pump room which is on the same level) occurred several years ago in the spring when the lower portion of the drain to the slough was frozen. Roof water from the spring rains filled the cistern end the overflow backed up through the boiler room floor drain since the slough outlet was blocked by ice. Some trouble is experienced each spring by similar freezing of the outlet from the boiler room floor drain but the cistern has not been killed at the same time and no flooding has occurred in recent years. There is slight possibility of the slough water rising enough to back up into the boiler room as the highest known level of the slough is some 1.7 feet lower than the boiler room floor, the level on May 20 being 2.7 feet lower than the floor.

"A repetition of the flooding of the lower levels of the building would be prevented by providing separate outlets for the boiler room floor drain and the cistern overflow. However, the outside drain pipes, being fairly shallow, would be likely to freeze and cause some degree of flooding. Therefore, I would recommend that the drainage be left as at present with a lamp hole being provided halfway between the building and the slough outlet so that a steam line from the boiler could be passed down the pipe to keep it thawed. The main drain should be uncovered at this point, a Y branch and 1/8th bend inserted in the line and tile pipe brought up to the ground surface and fitted with a wooden removable plug. This work is estimated to cost $25.00."

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.
"The cistern water has not been used for laundry purposes because of the fear of hardness and possible contamination from the refrigerator drain which discharged into the cistern. This drain has been diverted to discharge into the main laundry drainage system and the school authorities will use the cistern for the laundry as was originally intended. There is very small likelihood of any water overflowing from the cistern in future as both the school principal, Father Le Tour, and the school engineer, Mr. Dubois, are now advised of the circumstances leading to flooding.

(2) Septic Tank

"The school septic tank was completely full of sludge at the time of my visit and it is very evident that much of the troublesome odour is due to lack of cleaning. The tank was built in 1930 and was completely cleaned in 1935 and partially cleaned in 1938. Apparently the objectionable odour was not noticed until a year after each cleaning. Father Le Tour, the principal, will have the tank cleaned at the end of this month when the children are away. Periodic cleaning of the tank will, I believe, relieve the condition complained of.

"I am forwarding under separate cover tracing of sketch plan showing septic tank details as obtained from plans of the original installation supplemented by information supplied by the school engineer. The capacity of the septic chamber is ample for a school population of 130 and there is no sign of obstruction in the discharge pipe for the effluent. However, the existing manhole is small and not well placed for cleaning the tank and I would recommend that an additional manhole be built as indicated on the tracing.

"It is also apparent that the tank is poorly ventilated as the soil inlet is an elbow and there is no direct connection from the air space in the tank to a vent pipe. I would therefore recommend that the inlet elbow be replaced by a tee. The odours complained of apparently come from gas escaping into the pump well and from there to the school. To prevent this, all openings in the pump well should be fitted with airtight hatches and these should be kept closed. The estimated cost of these alterations and modifications is $125.00."

It will be noted that Mr. Cornish is of the opinion that the freezing of the drain and consequent flooding of the boiler room can be prevented by making provision for thawing the drain at a cost of $25.00; also that the objectionable odour from the septic tank could be prevented by cleaning out the tank. To facilitate this he recommends that an additional manhole be constructed. The cost of this and some slight alterations to prevent the escape of gas is estimated to be $125.00.

Mr. Walker states that this work can be carried out by the School Authorities without further reference to this office.
While at the School Mr. Cornish inspected other facilities and regarding Fire Protection stated as follows:

"The fire escapes are in good condition but in many cases hard of access from the second floor where access doors are in staff rooms with a bed placed across the opening which is consequently secured closed and blocked against drafts."

It is suggested that this condition be brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch.

T. S. Miller
Chief Engineer.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Re: Fire Escapes at the Blue Quill Indian Residential School.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th inst re above and quoting Engineer's Cornish's report, he stated the facts as you and I are aware of them but he did not offer a remedy and for your information Mr. Cornish, Father Letour and myself discussed what might help the situation, however like so many more reports, it still leaves the man in the field on the "spot".

You are aware of the plan of the staff rooms covering the approaches to the fire escapes on the second floor of the school and to refresh your memory find plan attached. You will readily see the difficulty of placing a bed in the rooms. To say the doors are blocked against drafts is purely, I mildly, I was in the rooms in the middle of the day last winter and to say they were drafty and cold would be a misstatement of facts, they were more like being in an open cockpit airplane at 50 below zero. It was just impossible to keep them habitable, with the inside door left open, they are still very very cold.

In your note attached you mention my monthly reports in which I have inspected or referred to fire escapes, they are constantly in my mind. You also mention "fire Proof" building - which the school staff always refer to the building as fire proof - you call it semi-fire proof. On the 19th July I went thru all the plans and specifications at the school to see if there is any reference to "fire proof", there apparently is not. However I have inspected the school very carefully this summer and there is no wood used in the construction even all floors are concrete also staircases and the roof is supported with wire rods. The building would undoubtedly appear fire proof.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, when at the school on the 19th July we discussed the fire escapes and approaches at length.

On your next inspection, we will check them together.

Re Blue Quill's Residential School.

I beg to report that the roof of the above school is leaking in about six or eight places around vents, also the roof of the laundry is leaking.

For your information I have checked the leaks and as you will be aware to repair leaks on the built up roofs is a very difficult task and must be very carefully done or else they become worse. I would recommend that a Professional Roofer be employed from Edmonton, to insure that a good repair job is made. For your information I do not know of a first class roofer in St. Paul district. I have discussed the matter with the Principal Father L.C. Latour and he is of the same opinion.

In regards to an estimate of the cost I am not in a position to give this owing to the work that might be entailed to make a good job of the leaks. I would further state that in six leaks and the ceiling over the laundry, damage is being caused to the plaster.

I would ask authority to get this work underway as soon as possible.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

AIR MAIL

Mr. W.P.B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alta.

I have your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to the roof at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

From the information given in your letter it is difficult for the Department to estimate what the probable expenditure would be. If you think that the repairs could be made at a cost not exceeding $150, we have no objection to your proceeding at once. However, if the possible expenditure exceeds the amount stated, it is felt that an estimate should first be obtained and submitted for our consideration. I agree that it is essential that the roof should be repaired, but at the same time the specific amount provided in our appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Blue Quills School has already been expended in providing the material requested for the hog pen.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Needed Equipment at Blue Quills School

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Your dietitian in her report on the above Indian school dated November 4, 1947, recommended the following equipment and alterations:

1. Installation of proper dishwashing and pot washing facilities.
2. Replacement of cook stove.
3. Enlargement of walk-in refrigerator.
4. Large cook's table,
5. Potato peeler.
6. Electric mixer.
7. Cooking utensils - kettles, mixing bowls and knives.
8. A large tank for a continuous supply of hot water.
9. Repair of flooring in kitchen, diningroom and dishwashing room.

When the above have been provided for it is hoped that the school will be in a better position to satisfy the requirements of your expert in nutrition.

This school has no hen house and this has been a serious handicap for the supply of proper food for the children. When I visited this institution last fall, I told the then Acting Principal that I would do my best to bring this matter to your attention. It is the intention of Reverend Father Bernet-Rollande to secure plan for a hen house large enough for 400 hens. When this has been done, and the quantity of lumber and materials made out, I shall present the list to your Department for its approval.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Flourde, O.M.I.
January 29, 1948.

Dear Father Plourde:

We have your letter of the 27th instant with reference to equipment recommended by the dietitian for the Blue Quills Residential School.

As you are aware, some of the equipment recommended has not been supplied to residential schools in the past. In addition, our funds are so limited at the present time that we are not in a position to consider heavy expenditures.

The contents of your letter will receive further consideration after April 1st.

It is noted that the principal intends to request materials for the erection of a hen house. The Department hopes that he will give careful consideration to the matter before presenting his request. Care should be taken not to provide a hen house larger than is absolutely necessary.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Material for Hen-House and Brooder at Blue Quills School

My dear Mr. Phelan,

As requested I am enclosing two estimates supplied by the following:

1. Hayward Lumber Company Limited,
   Edmonton, Alberta

2. The Imperial Lumber Company Limited,
   St. Paul, Alberta

for material needed to erect a colony brooder house and double deck laying house for the above institution.

This school has been without a hen-house or any facilities for keeping chickens for several years past and your dietitian has found fault with this handicap, and has suggested the immediate construction of such a building. The brooder is for the raising of baby chicks and is quite essential at the present time on any farm.

The principal wants to start construction of both the brooder and the hen-house immediately so as to be able to have them ready for the coming season. I might add that these estimates were made from plans supplied by the Federal Branch of Agriculture.

Hoping that you will give this matter your immediate attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Encl. 2.
Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $135.89 to purchase materials required for the erection of a brooder house at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

As there is no mention of labour it is presumed that the school management will do the necessary work in erecting this house without cost to the Department.

Owing to the lack of funds it is not possible for us to consider allowing the amount requested for the hen house. We will give the matter further consideration after April 1st when we know what amount will be available in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49 but at the present time I am not in a position to give you definite assurance that the amount requested will be available. In the meantime I would like to know if we supply the materials whether the school management will do the work without cost or if an expenditure will be necessary for labour. In the latter event, we would like to know the approximate cost of labour so that we will have an adequate picture of the whole transaction.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Blue Quills School.

This will advise that I have made a recent check on the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, and certain repairs that are required. You may recall on your last visit to Saddle Lake Agency, that we paid the School a visit, and one point brought up by the Rev. Father Rollande concerned the roof.

There are about four places on the roof that will require repairing. I have made various enquiries in and around St. Paul in an endeavour to obtain prices from various contractors for the repairing of the roof, and I find that the majority of them have a full season lined up. I have one letter here from Mr. B. B. HOLLINGER of the Mid-West Insulation Service, (copy of which is attached) and I would like to know if it would be in order to have him come out as soon as possible, and get his prices not only on repairing the roof, but there are approximately 145 windows that should be caulked. I noticed during the cold part of the winter, that the rooms were very drafty and hard to keep warm. There is no doubt in my mind that the windows was the cause for same, and would be of great help to the fuel account should it be possible to have them caulked. All the houses here at the Agency were caulked by the Mid-West Insulation Service, and I feel they were vastly improved for winter conditions.

I would like to see this work completed between the first part of July, and the first of September, and in the meantime would greatly appreciate any advice in this regards.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent,

Would authority be granted to call for tenders on the repairs to the roof and the insulating, as suggested by Mr. Taylor? I do know the roof must be repaired, as it is leaking badly in spots and damage is being done.

While at Saddle Lake yesterday Mr. Connolly, Supervising Engineer Indian Health Services, and I were asked to look over the residential school, particularly refrigeration, roofs, and windows.

The present refrigeration is a well insulated room 6' x 8', adjacent to a pantry off the main kitchen. The Principal wants more space, part of it to be cooled below 32 degrees where he can keep meat, in other words a freezer. Our opinion is that the present refrigerator would make the freezer and that the pantry should be insulated and turned into ordinary refrigeration. Miss Macready visited this school. Her report should be on file somewhere. I regard the project as important to health and Mr. Connolly says that it is feasible.

We went over the tar and gravel flat roofs, which cover the whole school building. They are 16-17 years old and are leaking. A Mr. Marchand, who talked as if he knew the business, is mending and patching the roofs without guarantee of payment. Mr. Connolly and Mr. Marchand agree that the whole roof will have to be replaced next year. All that can be done at this time is to patch the bad places so as to minimize interior damage during the winter and spring. One of the objects of this letter is to hope that some arrangement can be made to ensure the patching and the payment of Mr. Marchand for doing it. He seems to have done about $150.00 worth of work up to date.

Mr. Marchand was actually officially engaged to caulk the window frames. He found that there was as much leaking space around the sash as between the frames and brickwork. There is a curious arrangement of weather stripping consisting of a loose slat of hardwood at each side of the sash, fitting into the groove in which the sash slides up and down. Mr. Marchand is nailing on some of these slats, the only feasible emergency repair, and not a bad one. This work is not covered by his engagement for caulking. It is thought that $500 worth of time and materials will be required to make these windows reasonably weatherproof.

Reference your file 11801-5 (E.1) dated May 4th, 1948, this will advise that I have taken the matter up with Rev. Father Rollande, as requested, concerning a hen house for the School.

To date there has been no facilities at Blue Quills for chickens and all eggs have been purchased for use at the School and at times purchasing of same was practically impossible.

The plans and materials listed were obtained from Experimental Farm Services, Department of Agriculture, Ottawa, Ontario. They are for a double deck laying house, size - 25 ft. x 31 ft., 2 storey. The Rev. Principal has purchased 150 Plymouth Rock pullets and I concur with his figures that this number of chickens are required. During the school term 1947 - 48 there were approximately 167 children in attendance.

The reason for the double deck laying house is to keep non-laying hens from mixing with the layers and thusly the non-layers can be fattened for consumption at the school. This, without a doubt, would be cheaper than buying meat.

I am attaching a copy of the building plans for your consideration, and would respectfully request that they be returned if same appear to be satisfactory.

I was informed that the school has no carpenters for this project, and the cost of construction was omitted on the original estimate by the principal. I spent some time at the Blue Quills Residential School. There are 167 pupils registered and 164 were in attendance. There are four classrooms. All teachers are Nuns. Dear Mr. Neary:

Re Blue Quill Indian School,
St. Paul, Alberta.

You will recall my conversation with you on October 12th last with reference to the installation of natural gas and heating in the above school. At that time you contemplated sending your engineer to St. Paul to check into the costs, and at the time of our conversation we figured the costs at approximately $15,000.00, and that you would include this item in your Estimates for 1949.

I do not know whether your engineer has had the time to visit the school and check into the costs, but I am enclosing a tender from the St. Paul Foundry Limited, and I am very pleased to note that the total cost is only $11,650.00, which is considerably less than my estimate.

This cost will be made up, not only in a saving of fuel costs to the school but in convenience and cleanliness and regulated heat, which will prevent illness among the students and faculty. The cost of decorating from time to time will, in itself over a period of years, return the cost of this installation.

The burning of coal in this school has been extremely expensive,
not only due to the high cost of the coal itself but in hauling charges from the railroad siding and the taking away of the ashes, and there will also be a saving in the operational costs as it will not require a full time engineer and fireman.

Insurance rates should be reduced because this installation covers all safety features.

The advantages of natural gas over any other type of fuel are so well known that it is not necessary for me to say anything further. I most heartily recommend your serious consideration of this installation.

Yours very truly,

Walter F. Thorn.

Attention Supt. of Indian Education:

Re: Blue Quills Indian Residential School,

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your letter of April 30th, under File 751-5(E.1), and I beg to report as follows:

I have given this matter considerable study, and would recommend that the unfinished building be completed for the following reasons:

(1) There are approximately 150 children of the R.C. faith not in attendance at School, and two or three Day Schools will have little or no effect on this matter of keeping the Blue Quills School filled.

(2) There is no building available at this School for Manual Training, and the School is filled to capacity.

(3) Should more Indian Pupils be desirous of a higher Education, despite the fact we have Day Schools on the Reserves, I feel this Building would be of great value.

(4) At a recent Band Meeting at the Cold Lake Indian Reserve, I learned that this Band are against a Day School, and would recommend that they attend the Blue Quills School until such time as other arrangements could be made.

Further to the above this will advise that I have gone over the building with our Local Hayward Lumber Co. Agent, his Superintendent, and a Mr. Wilson contractor from Lloydminster, Sask. They gave me the following estimations. The Cement work (foundation, floors, etc.) and the Frame Work (walls, studing, etc.) at the present rates would cost in the vicinity of $8,000.00, and in the neighborhood of $20,000.00 to complete the building. This would include Material, Labour, Heating, and Lighting. Their prices for the demolishing of the building were $4,000.00, or $2,000.00 and materials salvaged, and this would mean a total loss for the Cement work.

The plans for this building were originally for
a Brick building, but under the existing circumstances, I do not feel that this would be satisfactory, as the quality of brick today is very poor, and prices extremely high. The quotations given me were for insulation and insul-brick on the outside. The dimensions of this building are; 40 feet wide, 80 feet long, two stories with 12 foot ceilings.

I have quoted the facts above, that you may determine a little of the situation as it stands today. I would be able to obtain a more definite estimate on the completion of the building, but the estimate would not be far either way on $30,000.00. Mr. Wilson (contractor) informed me that he would rather give an estimate on day labour, than on a contract basis. His reasons were that a certain amount of the structure would have to be taken down, and rebuilt, as they are by no means suitable for a building of this size, and the parts to be taken down would take more time in order to salvage any of the material, than would the time and cost of straightforward building. On the east end of the building the foundation is cracked in two places, but would easily be repaired. The Cement floor is in a very good condition. The walls were partly insulated with shavings, but this would have to be removed, and re-insulated as part of the shavings have been ruined from weather conditions and exposure.

I will endeavour to obtain any further information required, should it be felt that the building will be completed.

I have informed the principal of the School on the last part of your letter, but this matter will be taken up under separate letter.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

Memorandum

Re: Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
St Paul-de-Métis, Alberta.

In accordance with the request made by Major MacKay, our Mr. Hargreaves visited the above on his recent inspection trip to Alberta and British Columbia. The following report is submitted for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

The above institution is located about two miles west of the Town of St Paul-de-Métis, and it can be stated that it is one of the best kept buildings of all those visited by our officer to date.

The difficulties experienced in heating the building under severe weather conditions can be laid in part to a rather poor quality of coal which is hand fired, and in a large measure to the choice of the original piping design. As in many other cases in schools of similar layout, the piping distribution system was based on a vapour system designed to operate on several ounces of pressure. The ends of the mains are bled into a system of wet returns which means that no traps are used. This results in short circuiting when the pressure is raised in an attempt to obtain distribution of steam to the farthest points of the system. It will not be difficult or expensive to correct this phase of the design. The installation of float and thermostatic traps at the ends of the mains and branch mains will permit normal operating pressures of one to two lbs. per square inch to be used and will prevent short circuiting.

The heating system is served by two fire box type steel low pressure steam heating boilers. These boilers have been in service since the school was built and while they are not in the best condition, it is felt that they can provide several years of additional service.

The domestic hot water requirements cannot be served by the existing equipment. It is evident that insufficient consideration was given to the normal demands, in addition to which no distribution piping layout was made. The domestic hot water storage tank and the jacket heater are of capacities sufficient only to meet the light summer load.

One of the principal reasons for visiting this school was to investigate the possibility of converting from coal firing to natural gas firing. On February 24th a memorandum was received from Major MacKay together with an attached copy of a proposal to change to gas firing, prepared by the St. Paul Foundry Limited. We were requested to comment on this proposal at that time, but it was felt that our comment should be deferred until our heating engineer was able to carry out an inspection of the building.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
The St. Paul Foundry Limited proposition dated January 11th outlined the work involved in connection with converting the boilers to gas firing and piping gas from the nearest source. The St. Paul Utilities Company have requested permission to drill a well on the school property, their intention being to connect this well to an existing gas well which serves the entire town.

The St. Paul Foundry Limited estimated on piping the gas from the nearest source, (presumably the proposed new well), to the school; the erection and equipping of a Regulating Station to include regulators, orifices, flanges, heaters, drips, pump, odorizer, motoring equipment, etcetera, plus converting the combustion chambers of the school boilers, installing burners, controls, etcetera. Their price was $11,650.00. It is felt that if this work is approved and tendered a lower price will be submitted by one or more competitive firms in the area.

In summary it can be stated that substantial savings in fuel costs will be realized if natural gas is provided. It would appear to be an extravagance to equip this building with stokers in lieu of gas burners, but some means of automatic firing is much to be preferred over hand firing in an institution of this size. After full consideration having been given, it is recommended that the following operations be carried out in order to bring this school up to a normal point of efficiency.

(a) Install float and thermostatic traps at ends of all steam mains and branch mains.

(b) Provide new 900 gallon domestic hot water storage tank.

(c) Provide new indirect steam fed heater with self contained regulating valve; unit to have a capacity to heat 600 gallons of water per hour through 100 degree raise.

(d) Provide new condensation pump and receiver to replace ineffective boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.

(e) It is considered advisable to take advantage of the natural gas supply and to convert from coal firing to gas firing.

(f) Several minor operations will be necessary in conjunction with the above work which will be covered in the plans and specifications which will be prepared when approval is given.

Until plans and specifications have been outlined, it will be difficult to estimate within close limits the cost of these revisions. It is felt however that the sum of $15,000.00 will cover all the work outlined above.

Should these operations be carried out, this school would become one of the best equipped and most efficiently run institutions of its kind. It should be borne in mind that the boilers will likely have to be replaced within five or ten years time.

Chas. H. Buck,
for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.
Ottawa, July 20th, 1949.

ALTERATIONS AND REVISIONS TO STEAM HEATING AND DOMESTIC HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS

1. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying plan Index No.912 Sheet M.1/1, are intended to provide for such alterations and revisions to the heating system as are noted, and for the installation of a complete new domestic hot water supply system, in the building mentioned as indicated under the following sub-headings:

(a) Disconnect and remove existing piping at boilers.

(b) Disconnect and remove existing boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.

(c) Provide and install new piping at boilers as shown on plan.

(d) Provide and install new condensation pump and receiver with motor where shown on plan.

(e) Provide and install new float and thermostatic traps etc., on steam and branch mains where noted on plan.

(f) Provide and install new domestic hot water storage tank where shown on plan.

(g) Provide and install new indirect steam fed heater where shown on plan.

(h) Provide and install new temperature control unit for hot water supply as noted on plan.

(i) Convert boilers and other heating equipment to gas firing.

(j) All miscellaneous items required to complete the revisions as noted on plan or hereinafter specified, or as may be required, shall be supplied under this contract.

The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, material and plant, and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done, including damage to any part of the building incident to the installation of the work.

2. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor must visit the Site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

All work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner by workmen skilled in this trade, and special attention shall be given exposed work so that it be neatly erected with pipes plumb and true.

All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times, with adequate provision for expansion, and due attention given to the grading of pipes.
4. RULES AND REGULATIONS

All work shall be done in accordance with rules, regulations and recommendations as may be laid down by local or other authorities controlling such work. This Contractor shall file all necessary plans with such authorities and pay all necessary fees for permits, etc., as may be required.

5. CUTTING AND PATCHING

The Contractor shall be responsible for all cutting of holes through walls, floors, ceilings and roofs, incident to his work, and shall be required to patch up to match existing wall, floor, ceiling and roof finishes in the area affected. Skilled workmen shall be employed for this work and it shall be carried out to the satisfaction of the representative of the Chief Architect.

6. PIPING

New hot water supply shall be connected to the present distribution system in such a manner that the existing supply system may be used when boilers are shut down.

All new piping to be of sizes shown on drawing and connections shall be made substantially as indicated.

Remove existing steam piping from point indicated on plan to boilers, and replace with new as shown on plan.

All new steam piping and return mains shall be standard black steel pipe put together with cast iron screwed fittings, and with eccentric reducing couplings and unions, screwed or flanged where required. All pipe shall be carefully reamed before assembly and pipe compound shall be applied to pipe threads only.

All water piping up to 2" in diameter is to be galvanized steel pipe. Over 2" in diameter use black steel pipe.

All new piping shall be tested to 100 lbs pressure before covering is applied.

7. COVERING

All exposed cold water piping, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered 1" thick with anti-sweat wool felt sectional covering consisting of two 4" layers, each of which shall have been so fabricated by its manufacturer as to have a double thickness of asphalt per both inside and outside, stapled in place and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on. Risers in partitions will not be covered.

All hot water supply pipes, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered with 1" thick 4-ply asbestos aircell sectional pipe covering carefully butted and fitted around hangers, etc., and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on.

Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with asbestos cement and covered with cotton as specified for pipes.

Hot water storage tanks and heaters shall be covered with 1" thick 4-ply asbestos aircell blocks, wired in place, and plastered 1" thick with long fibre asbestos cement applied in two coats, the last coat to be tempered with 10 per cent Portland cement and trowelled to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with waterproof paint of an approved colour.

All steam mains shall be covered with 4-ply 1" thick asbestos aircell sectional pipe covering, carefully butted and fitted around hangers where such occur, finished with factory cotton pasted on.
Elbows, tees, valves etc., shall be covered with long fibre asbestos cement wrapped with cotton as specified for pipes. Flanges, unions and return mains need not be covered unless noted on plan.

8. HANGERS

Horizontal runs of water piping shall be supported at 8'-0" intervals with rod and ring hangers. No grabber bar allowed.

9. VALVES

Valves generally for steam and water piping, shall be gate valves unless otherwise mentioned, 2" and under shall be all brass. Over 2" shall be iron body valves with bronze trimmings.

10. TESTING

Water piping. Contractor will test all water piping before covering, using cold water at 100 lb. pressure.

11. FLOAT AND THERMOSTATIC TRAPS

Provide and install on steam and branch mains, as detailed on plan, new float and thermostatic traps of an approved type complete with all valves, strainers, scale pockets, unions etc., connect to existing wet return lines. Trap capacity at water heater shall be as noted on plan.

12. DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK

Provide, install, and connect one new domestic hot water storage tank where and as noted on plan. Pressure relief valve shall be installed where shown on plan and set at 70 p.s.i.

13. DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK STAND

Provide and install new domestic hot water storage tank stand consisting of six (6) upright 3" steel pipes with flanged base supports and capped ends. These shall be braced in both directions.

14. DOMESTIC HOT WATER HEATER

Provide and install as noted on plan new indirect steam fed heater with cast iron shell and copper tube element equal to type "J" Alco as made by A.S. Leitch Co. of Canada Ltd. Connect with new domestic hot water storage tank providing all necessary valves and fittings as shown or as may be required.

Provide and install on steam line to heater one self-contained temperature regulating valve with dial thermometer and temperature adjustment complete with bulb and tube as noted on plan.

15. CONDENSATION PUMP

The Contractor shall remove existing boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.

Provide, install and connect new condensation pump equal to C.A. Dunham Co. Ltd. # C-1015 having a capacity of 10,000 square feet E.D.R. Pump shall be complete with motor (½ H.P. single phase 110 volts, A.C.) welded steel tank equipped with float switch and mounting saddles, mounted on integral base.
16. INSTALLATION OF NATURAL GAS FOR HEATING AND KITCHEN USE

(a) Gas Main

Provide and install gas main from new gas well (presently being established under another contract) on school property, to the school building. This installation shall include:

(i) 4000 feet (approx) seamless tubing of suitable size to service peak loads.

(ii) 4000 feet (approx) ditching and covering.

(iii) Welding and testing of main.

(iv) Cleaning, application of prime, fabric wrapping and asphalt.

(v) Valves, drips, blowdown etc, as may be necessary.

(b) Regulating Station

Provide and erect Regulating Station building to house regulators, orifice flanges, heaters, drips, pump, odorizer, metering equipment and etc., which shall be assembled with valves, piping, fittings and other equipment as may be necessary.

(c) Gas Installations in Building

(i) Heating Boilers - Provide and install in each boiler gas conversion burner, equal to "Triumph" Port Burner, Series E, as made by Charles L. Lehman Co, Edmonton. The burner must be able to provide each boiler with a minimum of 1,300,000 B.T.U. per hour.

(ii) Dominion Radiator Bungalow Heater B-32 - Provide and install in above heater a suitable conversion gas burner, able to provide a minimum of 64,000 B.T.U. per hour.

(iii) Kitchen Domestic Hot Water Supply - Provide and install a suitable indirect, closed coil, gas fired, domestic hot water heater for kitchen domestic hot water supply.

(iv) Kitchen Range - Provide and install burners suitable for existing kitchen range.

(v) Miscellaneous - The Contractor shall provide and install all automatic appliances and safety controls, pipes, valves, fittings, etc., for the complete installation. He shall comply with such Provincial and Fire Underwriters Regulations as apply. Boiler pressures to be controlled in range from one (1) to three (3) pounds.

(d) Refractory Linings

Where applicable, the Contractor shall furnish and install suitable refractory linings of an approved type consistent with the conversion to gas firing of the above mentioned equipment.

(e) Guarantee

The Contractor will be called upon to submit on completion of this work (outlined in section 16), his written guarantee that these installations will operate the above with maximum efficiency at
17. AUTOMATIC BOILER FEEDWATER REGULATORS

Provide and install where shown on plan automatic boiler feedwater regulators of an approved make and of size in accordance with the manufacturers' recommendation, designed to definitely maintain boiler water level at all times. Regulators to be furnished with low water cut-off and cold water supply for boiler connected thereto.

18. BUILDING OPENING FOR DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK INSTALLATION

Remove windows from rear wall of boiler room install tank, and replace windows.

19. CONTROL EQUIPMENT

The Contractor shall furnish and mount where shown on plan, where directed or where may be required, all thermostats, aquastats, and other automatic, electrical or other control equipment for temperature and pressure regulation, of approved manufacture, suitable capacity and electrical characteristics shown on plan or specified. All wiring will be done by the electrical contractor.

20. COMPLETION

Upon completion, the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

21. RECORD PLANS

During progress of the work, the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans. Upon completion, he shall forward one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red to the Chief Architect. Blueprints for this purpose shall be furnished by the Department.

22. GUARANTEE

Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period at his own expense and as soon as possible after having been notified in writing that such defect occurs.

Sir,

In accordance with instructions contained in the Director's letter dated May 27th last I proceeded to St. Paul de Metis from Calgary on July 2nd and visited the area reserved in connection with the proposed Indian Residential school.

On the morning of July 4th in company with Father La Rose, the Parish Priest, I examined a number of sites on sec.11, tp.38, rge.10 which it was thought were attractive from one or more viewpoints, finally locating what was considered the most desirable site. This site is on the highest land in the section and is in the NE¼ at about the point indicated on the attached sketch plan. A school building erected at this point would have good drainage facilities either to the southeast or southwest.

Water Supply.

On the afternoon of July 3rd and again on July 4th I personally investigated the water supply possibilities of this locality. There is no surface water supply either from lakes or streams in the locality. Lake St. Vincent located some 6 miles directly north is the only source of surface water which would be suitable but its location renders its use prohibitive.

Sub-surface supplies can be obtained at from 60 to 150 feet but in the majority of the wells drilled the water is very hard - quite unsuitable without treatment.

In section 12 two wells were examined at points indicated on the plan, and a sample of the more palatable water taken for examination, particularly for hardness. This well is drilled to 105 feet and has water standing 60 feet in the hole.

On the SW¼ of sec.10 which is owned by Mr. S. Tetreault, he has three drilled wells, two of which produce hard unpalatable water at depths of 66 to 70 feet and a third which produces excellent soft water at 60 feet. In this well a gravel stratum was penetrated at 60 feet from the surface and produced clear soft live water and apparently in quantity as it stands 30 feet in the hole, and Mr. Tetreault has never been able to lower it even when watering stock and filling tanks.

It is highly desirable that an effort be made to follow up this gravel lead into sec.11 and to locate the first drilling site on it.
Water is found at an average depth of 80 feet in this locality, but with few exceptions is hard and not suitable for general domestic use. In the town of St. Paul de Metis, 13 miles from section 11, the local creamery has drilled three wells and after only two years in operation the supply has not entirely given out. This, it is thought, is chiefly due to silting up at the suction with quick sand and fine silt, because new wells drilled close by will produce water at this elevation.

General Suitability of Location.

The section under reservation was carefully examined and its general topographical features noted. Soil conditions are suitable for agricultural purposes and the section is well wooded, affording excellent shelter belts for stock. There is a three-wire fence in poor condition around the section, and I estimated there were some 200 head of stock - horses and cattle - being pastured therein. The farmer on the adjoining section to the east thought there were nearer 300 head, but as the number varies from time to time it is not material. The pasture was in excellent condition and the stock looked well. There are several ditches or sloughs but only one contained any water, and this was almost exhausted owing to the dryness of the season in this locality.

Taking the following essentials into consideration it must be conceded that the section is suitable.

(a) **Locality** - proximity to railway and accessibility - i.e., roads of approach.

(b) **Topography** - general slope - drainage, etc.

(c) **Soil** - character and depth.

(d) **Water supply** - available surface water and probability of sub-surface supplies.

(e) **Power** - availability and cost.

The fact that a supply of electrical energy can be obtained by the construction of only 3.77 miles of power line at a cost of approximately $850.00 per mile was a point much in favour of this location as it will obviate the necessity for the installation of a separate power plant for light, laundry, water supply, fire protection, etc.

The Calgary Power Company is prepared to furnish power at the following rates:

**Power.**

Service charge of $1.00 per H.P. per month. For 1st 100 K.W. hours 6¢ and all over this amount @ 4¢ per K.W. hour.

**Lighting.**

Service charge 80¢ per month for first 500 Watts and 30¢ per month for each additional 250 Watts.

For first 100-hour use of installed capacity 12¢ per K.W. hour and all over at 6¢.
Recommendations.

(1) That as the ultimate success and safety of the proposed institution depends upon an adequate and satisfactory water supply, no site be selected until a systematic search has been made by drilling for a water supply.

(2) That should a supply of live soft water be found at a suitable depth, it be given a thorough pumping test before acceptance.

(3) That provision be made for the drilling of a series of test wells with a view to the discovery of the gravel formation which is yielding such excellent water in the section to the west.

(4) That if none of these shallow test holes finds a suitable supply a hole be drilled to a depth of 300 feet in the hope of striking fresh water below the existing water-table.

Conclusions.

From complete enquiries made at St. Paul de Metis I ascertained that there were no well drillers available in the vicinity. There is one man with a boring machine but it is very old and he has great difficulty in boring to a depth of 80 feet. A man with a modern well-drilling machine should be secured for this work. If authority is given to carry out the above recommendations enquiries will be made immediately and estimates obtained for the work. I may say that the parties with the boring machines used on the wells in the vicinity of St. Paul de Metis have been charging at the rate of $1.25 to $1.50 per foot.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

The test well on the site of the proposed Indian School near St. Paul, Alberta, which was being drilled for the Department of Indian Affairs, has been carried down to 461 feet. This was as deep as it was possible to go and drilling has been stopped.

The well was started with 5 5/8 casing and this was carried to 300 feet. At the 300-foot depth a string of 5-inch casing was used to 400 feet and from there 4½-inch casing was run. Water was first encountered at 100 feet. This water was very hard and unsuitable for the purpose for which it was required. Another vein of very hard water was reached at about 200 feet, but this was still of a very hard quality. Between the 300 and 400-foot level a very fine quality of soft water, suitable for drinking, laundry, and boiler purposes was reached. The difficulty with this supply is that it comes through sand which runs into the casing and pump. On this account it has not been possible to make a test of the quantity but the water is under considerable pressure and stands 375 feet in the casing.

It is proposed to experiment with a sand point and a casing screen in an endeavour to keep the sand from the casing and the suction pipe of the pump. It has also been suggested that if a pump could be operated on the well for some hours a cavity might be made in the sand formation which would form a settling basin for the sand and keep it clear of the casing.

The driller, Mr. Douglas, claims that when he contracted for the drilling of the well it was not considered that he would have to go more than 300 feet and that this should be considered a reasonable depth in the terms of his tender. The drilling below 250 feet, it is understood from our engineer's reports and from Mr. Douglas, has been very difficult and extremely expensive. Herewith is enclosed a schedule of rates which will satisfy Mr. Douglas and which appear to be reasonable. Certain cable for the deeper drilling was purchased for Mr. Douglas. This is being retained for the Department. It will be possible that this may be sold to Mr. Douglas on a reduction in cost, as he has taken contracts to drill other wells in the district.

Mr. Douglas is claiming that he should be paid at the rate of $10.00 per day for thirteen days. This was time lost when he had to cease operations waiting for instructions re purchase of 5-inch casing and later of 4-inch casing and the shipping of this casing to the drilling site. This would appear to be a just charge and it is recommended that it be allowed.

Enclosed herewith is a blue print of the log of the well.

Sir:

I beg to state that on March 12 I visited the town of St. Paul to inspect the well upon the NE¼ sec. 11, tp. 58, rgs. 19, W. 4th mer., drilled for the proposed R. C. Indian School at that point. It was necessary to ascertain whether that well was satisfactory for the purpose required or whether it should be abandoned and another well drilled.

Mr. J. G. Douglas, the well-driller, accompanied me to St. Paul and assisted in obtaining the depth to the water and to the quicksand in the well. This gentleman stated definitely to me that pumping would raise the level of the quicksand and ruin the well. However, it was considered advisable to apply a pumping test before the well should be condemned.

Mr. Douglass returned to Edmonton and I hired Mr. J. A. Salls, a local well-driller, and other help to install a pump and engine. It was necessary to get the loan of a new pump, pipe, rods and a cylinder from a local hardware merchant upon a ten per cent basis. Most of the other equipment such as a 1½ h.p. gas engine, tent, etc., was loaned without charge.

Since it was understood that the quicksand would rise rapidly it was decided to lower the cylinder only to a depth of 220 feet. The test was to be continuous day and night until definite results were obtained.

Test.

The pump was started at 10:32 a.m. on Friday and discharged 2.6 gals. per minute. The water was clear until 11:15 a.m. when a thick solution of dark clay was raised. This lasted 6 minutes when the flow ceased entirely. I then went to St. Paul to discuss the situation with Mr. Sexton, Manager of the local creamery, who had had some difficulty with wells at the creamery. It was decided to continue the pumping even if it were necessary to lower the cylinder to 300 feet.

With much difficulty four men got the pump started again at 1:19 p.m. The pump discharged about 3.7 gals. per minute until 1:54 p.m. and stopped, presumably for lack of water.

Pumping was resumed at 2:15 p.m. and continued steadily day and night until 9:35 a.m. Sunday. The water cleared considerably and contained at the last one teaspoonful of sand per gallon of water. At 9:35 a.m. the pump stroke was lengthened from four to six inches to increase the discharge and see what would happen. The discharge then continued at 5.0 gals. per minute for 30 minutes when much quicksand was raised. The discharge slowly decreased to about 3.5 gals. per minute and the water again cleared up considerably as before.
At 3 p.m. the pump ceased delivering water. The engine was giving trouble and a wooden upright from the pump-jack wore out, hence it was decided to pull out the pump and discontinue the test.

The cylinder was found clogged with sand but otherwise in good condition although it had pumped in the two days probably two cubic feet of sand and mud. The water level was found to be 98 feet from the top or 2 feet higher than when the test commenced. The mud and sand in the casing was 451.4 feet from the top or 11.0 feet lower than at the beginning of the test. It was considered that the entire contents of the casing at the commencement of the test were removed by pumping and that the material in the pipe at the end of the test was fresh material that had come into the pipe during pumping.

Summary.

| Description                                      | Measurement |
|--------------------------------------------------|-------------|
| Total depth of well                              | 461 ft.     |
| Depth to water at commencement of test           | 100 "       |
| Depth to mud and sand at commencement of test    | 420.4 "     |
| Duration of test                                 | 53 hrs.     |
| Average rate of discharge                        | 3.4 gals. per min. |
| Depth to pump cylinder                           | 220 ft.     |
| Quantity of sand pumped at 3.4 gals. per minute  | One teaspoonful per gal. of water. |
| Size of cylinder                                 | 3 ins.      |
| Size of pipe                                     | 1 1/2 "     |
| Water pumped per 24 hrs.                         | 4900 gals.  |

Conclusions.

The well was pumped steadily for two days at the rate of 4,900 gals. per day or 3.4 gals. per minute with apparently no injurious results. At this rate one teaspoonful of sand per gallon was lifted. Apparently 4,900 gals. per day represents the maximum capacity of the well with the cylinder at a depth of 220 feet, or 241 feet above the bottom. Since 241 feet of water represents a pressure of 105 lbs. per inch upon the bottom of the well, the capacity would no doubt be tremendously increased if the cylinder were lowered to the bottom of the well and no trouble were caused by quicksand.

Hence, it is my opinion that the present well will deliver for an indefinite period of time 2,500 gals. of water per 24 hours if pumped at the rate of 2.5 gals. per minute. The attached print shows a Fairbanks-Morse pump that will deliver water at this rate. It can be operated either by electricity or gasoline.

The specifications for this plant are as follows:

- No. of pump: 6669
- Power: Electricity
- Quantity of power: 1 h.p.
- Imperial gallons per minute: 150
- Cylinder stroke: 6 inches
- Size of cylinder: 1 1/2 inches
- Depth of cylinder: 220 feet
- Size of pipe (plugged and reamed): 2 inches
- Wooden pump rod 7/8 in. x 1 1/8 in. to be used.
- Use a long fine sand screen.
In regard to the life of this well, the data and information would indicate that it should improve with use. In conversation with Bill Morris, who assisted in the drilling and collected the samples for the geological department, I was informed that some gravel and clay were struck in the bottom of the well. The presence of even a small amount of gravel is very encouraging and would lessen the difficulty to be anticipated from quicksand.

Many other wells in that vicinity have improved with use in that the cloudy condition of the water and the amount of quicksand has decreased without any lessening in the discharge of water. For fire protection, garden purposes, stock, etc., another well or two drilled to about 150 feet will probably be required. There appears to be an abundance of water in that district at about that depth. This water is hard but quite satisfactory for drinking, cooking, stock and in fact for all purposes except washing. For the latter purpose the local farmers and residents of St. Paul use rain water and snow water. At the hospital a small softening plant is used for the wash water.

Amount of Water required for a School of 100 Residents.

It is noticed in other reports that a daily per capita consumption of 30 gals. is estimated. From information which I have, I believe this quantity will not be used under ordinary careful conditions of plumbing and use. Mr. C. J. MacKenzie, Dean of the University of Saskatchewan, assumed an estimated use for the town of Assiniboia of 20,000 gals. per day, or about 20 gals. per capita. The household winter consumption of water in Maple Creek with modern plumbing conditions as actually metered is between 10 and 15 gallons per day. Water should be more economically used when 100 people are concentrated under one roof than when living in 20 residences.

The amount of water required at the barn for stock is very small, probably 6 gals. per head for 40 head.

For fire protection a reservoir of about 20,000 gallons should be provided.

The water pumped for domestic purposes from the deep well should be delivered to two settling tanks before being pumped to the gravity or compression tank.

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. Merritt H. French.
In further reference to your letter of the 6th instant regarding the water supply system for the proposed new Indian school at St. Paul de Metis, I enclose herewith a report received from the Commissioner of Irrigation on a test made of the capacity of the well drilled last year by Mr. J.C. Douglas, on the North East quarter of Section 11, Township 58, Range 10, West of the 4th Meridian.

From this report you will note that a very thorough test of the well has been made and it would appear that we can rely upon from two and one-half to three imperial gallons per minute under steady pumping. This amount of water would be satisfactory for laundry purposes and possibly for drinking. The Commissioner recommends, however, that in order to ensure a satisfactory supply for the other requirements of the school and for fire protection that provisions should be made for the drilling of two additional wells at an estimated cost of about $550.00 per well. Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your No. 118-1-9 of the 22nd ultimo regarding the request of the Rev. Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School to have the new school farm fenced and some of the land broken.

I may say that breaking land at this time of the year would be inadvisable, in fact it would be useless. Land should not be broken later than the end of July, so that this work can be done next spring if the Department so desires. I should say that it would take from $8.00 to $10.00 an acre for the breaking of sixty or seventy acres.

The fencing can be done now or next spring. It would take about 1280 posts, 5000 pounds of wire, 200 pounds of staples, and the cost of labour would be about $25.00 a mile for four miles of fencing, making a total cost of about $700.00. If the money is available now this work might be proceeded with, otherwise it can be left until next spring.

Honourable Sir,

I beg to inform you that the cutting of branches on the new land of the Blue Quills School is over. The work has been given to Mr. Hector Thérien, of St Paul, by the conservative committee of St Paul, for the sum of $650.00.

Last week, I went over there, with the farmer of the school, to have a view of the work, and it is my idea and even that of my farmer that, according to the winter time during which the job was made, this could not be made better. However, I will point out that many stumps, chiefly willow stumps, have been left in the ground that could resist a common breaking outfit. Mr. Hector Thérien assures me that with his own machines, he can easily root up all these stumps, that suggests the breaking could be undertaken by this man.

Mr. Hector Thérien will charge $10.00 per acre, what means breaking, disking four times, picking up roots and stones, and harrowing. I will say this is the common price and should not be undertaken at a cheaper rate, according to those who wish to have the job.

Mr. Hector Thérien guarantees a very good job, and I know that he will do, because he is a honest man, and besides, knowing well the work to be done, he will not kick for the stumps left in the ground.

I hope that pretty soon I will hear that the contract of breaking has been given, as it is just the time now for this work.

In my last letter, I asked you, Honourable Sir, for the fence to be made as soon as possible, stating that the grass be kept for the animals of the school. But there is another reason for having this fence made the sooner; the animals that pasture on the land gather around the new building, teased by the flies, and it is to be feared that they break the windows. Mr. Gardner Smith spent one evening to chase them out, and I guess he will obliged to do so many times.

Your obedient Servant,

Rev. Jos. Anglin,
Principal.

July 7th 1931.

To the Honourable Duncan Scott,
Dept. Supt of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honourable Sir,

Yesterday, I went to St Paul to see about the new school, and I was surprised to hear that Mr Gardner Smith had left on account of sickness for one month and a half. Till now, nothing has been made for outbuildings, and I wonder if we can move this year.

Here, at Sacred-Heart, I did not raise any crop, thinking that it was useless, having a word from you that we would move about July. Then, for next winter, I have no feed and no straw for the livestock. Besides that, I have prepared nothing for wintering here, at Sacred-Heart, no wood for fuel, etc.

Finally, would it be possible to know from you where we shall winter, either here, at Sacred-Heart, and I will take steps for fuel, or at St Paul?

At the same time, I will get you remember that no breaking of land has been undertaken at the new school, and it is very time now for having it made; otherwise, I will have no crop yet next year.

In visiting the school yesterday, I remarked that many footsteps were seen on the floor, and even some black marks appeared on the walls. I supposed that people of St Paul had a dance in the school. Did you allow the school-keeper to give dances in the new school, or to admit so many visitors that they blacken the walls and soil the floors?

I hope, Honourable Sir, that you will give me, as soon as possible, an answer to this letter.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.

Sir:-

Referring to your letter No.118-1-9 of the 19th August last in regard to breaking and discing contract awarded to Mr. Jeremie Faucher, I beg to inform you that the breaking was completed some time ago but no discing has been done to date. For various reasons, but owing chiefly to stumps and roots on a portion of the plot, there was considerable delay in the work. On receipt of your letter above referred to, I advised the Reverend Principal that the Department was unable to authorize any expenditure for dragging, picking roots, stones, etc., and that the school authorities were expected to do this work. This work, however, not been done and on taking up the matter of completion of the contract with Mr. Faucher, he informed me that the discing could not be done satisfactorily over the roots and stones. On the 5th instant, I again interviewed Mr. Faucher regarding his contract. The Reverend Principal had apparently made the suggestion that Mr. Faucher pick the roots and stones and that two discings might be omitted to offset this work. Mr. Faucher did not feel inclined to do this, and when asked as to whether he could complete four discings this Fall, he informed me that he was very doubtful as there was now considerable frost in the ground and the job could not be done satisfactorily owing to this and the fact that the roots and stones had not been taken out.

There was about 10 acres of land on the main plot selected that, owing to water after the heavy September rains, Mr. Faucher could not break. However, he broke five acres adjoining the North side and the Reverend Principal asked him to break the two plots selected as playgrounds. This is also given as five acres so that the 100 acres of breaking called for in Mr. Faucher's contract has been completed. I might state that the breaking was satisfactorily performed.

Owing to the colder weather which might be expected at this time of year, Mr. Faucher asks that the discing be postponed until Spring and requests that he be paid for the breaking at the rate of $6.00 per acre. I should be glad to have your advice in the matter.

The Secretary,

SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA.

April 11th, 1934.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that W. Morrow and his wife recently separated leaving a child, Victoria Cryer Morrow, aged 5 years, with an Indian Charles Cryer and his wife who live on the Saddle Lake Reserve. Mrs. Morrow is a treaty Indian woman shown as Isabel Morrow No. 165 of the Saddle Lake Band, and while her husband is not a treaty Indian, this family have lived on the reserve more or less continuously for about fifteen years.

Charles Cryer and his wife are practically destitute and unable to provide for the child. In view of the conditions under which the little girl Victoria was being brought up, I considered it advisable to have the child taken out of their hands and in order to have her taken care of, I have asked the Reverend Principal of the Blue Quill's Residential school to take her in pending a report and further disposition of the matter. Under the circumstances, I would recommend that this child be admitted to the school. I might mention that pupil No. 232 of the Blue Quill's school is a brother of the Girl.

Mrs. Morrow is at present living on the Beaver Lake reserve and her husband has left the Reserve. I trust that the Department will approve of the action taken in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Gillion
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 21, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the admission of Victoria Morrow to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. I note that a brother of this girl was admitted to the Blue Quills School last fall, but, I would point out that, when the application for this boy was forwarded, the Department was not supplied with as complete information as is contained in your letter of the 11th instant.

Please let me know if Morrow is a white man. Every care must be taken, in admitting children to school, to make certain that they are fully eligible. Our primary obligation is to educate treaty Indian children, and, if we accept every half-breed that applies for admission, our schools will soon be over-crowded.

When replying, you should let me know if there are other children in this family and also with whom the mother is living at the present time and what she is doing.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
