May 12th, 1934.

Sir:

The Indians of this Agency have recently been asking as to whether the Department would consider favourably, the question of allowing the Indian children two months holidays during the year instead of the number of days allowed at present. The Indians claim that the children attending public schools are allowed two months holidays and in view of this, they are asking that their children be granted the same time.

Discussing this with the Reverend Principal of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school, I understood that the matter had been previously discussed and that the question would probably be taken up with the Department by some of the Principals of Indian schools.

I should be glad to know whether there are any prospects of a change being made and if so, whether it would apply this year.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant, with reference to the request that you have received from the Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School regarding holidays.

In this connection I enclose for your information a copy of circular letter of May 20, 1925. You will note that grant is only allowed for 43 days' holidays. If a principal of a residential school finds it necessary to allow longer holidays to any pupil, it should be on the distinct understanding that the Department will only pay grant for 43 days. For instance, if a pupil is allowed out on holidays on June first and does not return until September first, grant should only be requested for 73 days (30 days in September, plus 43 days' holidays). In the event of holidays longer than 43 days being allowed, the Principal should show plainly on his September quarter return the dates between which the annual leave was taken. You will note that the last paragraph of circular letter of May 20, 1925, contains instructions to this effect.

About a month ago, the Principal of the Blue Quills School wrote the Department requesting that he be allowed to take two months' holidays. We understood from his letter that he requested two months' holidays with grant and, on this understanding, the Department wrote him on May 9th. I enclose for your information a copy of our letter.

Honourable Sir,

I have your letter No 1-1-10, of June 15th, concerning the pupils of 16 years of age and over, and may say that I was surprised to read that the principals of schools need a special permission from the Superintendent General to keep them at school till 18 years of age. Since long time, it has been the general rule of the Department to retain the pupils at school till 18 years of age, and even farms have been adjointed to boarding schools in order to train the big boys from 16 to 18 years of age in farming, whilst the big girls should be trained in sewing and cooking.

If the pupils stay at school till they be 16 only, this means that this training in farming, sewing and cooking, will be suppressed.

For me, I have no reason to keep at school these big boys and girls who are 16 and over. However, I realize that the big girls should be retained at school till they be 18, which is the usual age of marriage, in order to prevent them from immorality on the reserves.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that Thomas Houle, an Indian of Goodfish Lake in the Saddle-Lake Agency, asks me to take his children into Blue Quills School.

Thomas Houle has been Protestant, but for marrying a Catholic woman, was converted to Catholic religion, was baptised by Rev. Father Comire, and promised to bring up his children in Catholic religion. Since his marriage, he did not practice Catholic religion, but did not return back to the Protestant one, and in fact, he had all his children baptised in Catholic church.

Two years ago, he had some children to put at school, and because not practising any religion, was asked for choosing the school where to put his children, Catholic or Protestant. It is stated that he chose the Protestant school, and in fact, one of his boys was sent to Edmonton Indian school. I suppose this boy did not stay long at school, as he is home since nearly 2 years, and has not been brought back to school.

Now Thomas Houle wishes to enter some children into Blue Quills school, not this one that was at Protestant school, but some other ones. What to do? Can I accept these children? According to the principle of the Indian Act, vid: that the Catholics must go to Catholic school and the Protestants to the Protestant one, all the children of Thomas Houle should have been admitted into a Catholic school, and not into a Protestant school; they have all been baptised in Catholic religion. More of that, the Department should see that the Indians keep their promise to bring up their children into the religion, where there is a promise as in the case of Thomas Houle.

Hoping to hear from you very soon in this connection, I remain,

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal

I have your letter No.18-1-10, of Nov.26th, referring to the telegram you received from me. This telegram is the reply to a telegram coming from Ottawa, signed Wm Foran, and termed as follows:

"Principal, Indian School, Saddle-Lake, Indian Agency, Saddle-Lake, Alta. Wire if you can arrange for and supervise examination December 8th approximately ten candidates". Wm Foran.

and in foot-note this:

"Rev. Father Angin: Mr Gullion advise this telegram is for you".

I could not understand this telegram, and I do not know who is Mr Wm Foran. I thought that Mr Foran was an employee of the Department of Indian Affairs, asking me if I could accept ten pupils more, into Blue Quills School. So I termed my telegram to you in consequence. But Mr Gullion, having received a second telegram, termed as the first one, came to see me and explained that Mr Wm Foran is a member of the civil service commission, asking me to supervise the examination of the ten candidates who applied for the clerkship of the Saddle-Lake Agency, this place being vacant by the clearance of Mr Sicard. After this explanation, I saw well my mistake about the telegram you received, and you must consider it as null.

As to the number of the pupils you state to be 136 at Blue Quill School, I may say that in fact this last number appears in the first column of the last quarterly return, but in fact I received grant for 121 only, the other ones being discharged, and it is the true number of pupils we have just now. You see then there is yet place at Blue Quills School for 10 pupils and more.

Being sorry to have troubled you with this telegram, I remain

Yours truly,

Le 11 Mars 1935

À l'attention du Surintendant de l'Éducation Indienne,
Ottawa.

Monsieur le Surintendant,

J'ai l'honneur de vous rendre compte que je n'ai reçu aucune réponse du Département des Affaires Indiennes au sujet des enfants de Thomas Houle de Goodfish-Lake. Cet I., disant à demandé de mettre ses enfants à l'école Blue Quills et je vous rappelle que ces enfants ont été baptisés catholiques. J'apprends aussi que l'agent de Saddle-Lake fait des efforts pour placer à l'école protestante d'Edmonton une fille dénommée Flora Lewis, orpheline, adoptée par Joseph Gladu de Whitefish-Lake; cette fille est catholique, née de parents catholiques. J'ai su que les 5 petits-enfants de Sam Bull de Goodfish-Lake ont été acceptés pour l'école protestante d'Edmonton, bien que la mère en mourant ait demandé qu'ils soient élevés à l'école catholique. Tout cela me confirme dans mon opinion que l'Agent de Saddle-Lake travaille pour l'école d'Edmonton qui n'est pas son école et au contraire ne fait rien pour l'école Blue Quills qui est son école même les catholiques sont envoyés à l'école protestante d'Edmonton sous prétexte que les parents le demandent. Est-ce que le principe de l'Acte Indien qui veut que les catholiques aillent à l'école catholique et les protestants chez les protestants existe encore? Ou bien est-ce que les agents ont reçu des ordres spéciaux pour aider les écoles protestantes et au contraire auraient reçu des ordres pour ne pas aider les écoles catholiques? L'Agent de Saddle-Lake peut se fendre en quatre pour travailler pour l'école protestante d'Edmonton, recruter des enfants et remettre les déserteurs sur le train de Spedden à Edmonton; mais il ne bougera pas pour l'école Blue Quills; non seulement cela, mais il enlève les enfants catholiques pour les mettre à l'école protestante.

J'ai parlé de cette question aux autres Principaux d'écoles indiennes à notre dernière convention, et ils m'ont dit que les mêmes faits se présentent chez eux. Alors nous, catholiques, nous serions traités comme des citoyens de deuxième zone? c'est bon à savoir et nous ferons notre possible pour faire cesser cet état de choses. En attendant, je vous serais bien obligé de me dire si je puis accepter les enfants de Thomas Houle; 2) Je demande que Flora Lewis soit placée à Blue Quills 3) Je demande aussi que dorénavant les enfants baptisés catholiques soient envoyés à l'école catholique et que les enfants baptisés protestants soient envoyés à l'école protestante, et cela sans égard pour les parents qui changent de religion plus souvent que de chemise.

Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Surintendant, mes salutations,

Rev. Jos Angin,
Principal

St. Paul, Alta., March 11, 1935
To the Superintendent of Indian Education
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that I have received no reply from the Dept. of Indian Affairs concerning the children of Thomas Steele of Goldfish Lake. This Indian has requested to send his children to the Blue Quills school and I wish to remind you that these children were baptised Catholics. Also hear that the Agent of Saddle Lake is making efforts to place at the protestant school of Edmonton a girl named Flora Lewis orphan, adopted by Joseph Gladu of Whitefish Lake; that girl is catholic born from catholic parents. I have learned that the 23 grand children of Sam Bell of Goldfish Lake were accepted at the protestant school of Edmonton although the mother in living farther that they be brought up in the catholic school. All this confirms my opinion that the Agent of Saddle Lake works for the school of Edmonton which is not his school and on the contrary does not do a thing for the school of Blue Quills which is his school; there are even catholics sent to the protestant school of Edmonton under the pretext that the parents are asking for it. Is the principle of the Indian Act that specifies that the catholics must go to the catholic school and the protestants to the protestant school does still exist? Or otherwise, have the Agents received special orders to help the protestant schools and on the other hand been given orders not to
help the catholic schools? The Agent of Saddle Lake is rather busy to work for the protestant school of Edmonton, to recruit children to put deserted back on the train of Stephen to Edmonton; but he wants not more a finger for the school of Blue Quills; not only that, he takes catholic children and sends them to the protestant school.

Spoke of this matter to the other school Principals of Indian schools at our last convention, and they told me that the same facts are happening with them. Consequently we, catholics, are treated as citizens of second rate? This is good to know and we will do our utmost to have that state of affair cease. In the meantime, I would be much obliged if you would tell me if I could accept the children of Thomas House;

2°. I demand that Frank Lewis be placed at Blue Quills.

3°. I demand also that in future the children baptised catholic be sent to the catholic school and those baptised protestant be sent to the protestant school, and that without paying attention to parents who are changing religion often than they remove their shirt.

Kindly accept this my best regards

[Signature]
Rev. Jos. Augie
Principal
Ottawa, March 22nd, 1935.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to requests that you have received for the admission of certain children to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

I would like to assure you that the Department gives very careful consideration whenever there is any doubt regarding the religious auspices under which a child should be educated. Such cases occur more or less frequently at practically all Indian residential schools and several factors have to be considered before a decision can be made. This involves several letters and it necessarily follows that considerable time must elapse before a final decision is made.

The Department is not yet prepared to decide where the children of Thomas Houle should be educated but the matter is receiving consideration and, in the meantime, of course, the children must not be placed in any Indian residential school.

We do not appear to have any correspondence on file with reference to the case of Flora Lewis. I note your statement that the Agent is endeavouring to place her in the Edmonton Residential School. He is being written and requested to report at once.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. Jos. Angin, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Sir,

Included among these applications were those of William G. Erasmus, Beatrice Olive Erasmus and Elmer Charles Erasmus. The application forms for their admission were signed by their grandfather, Sam Bull.

The Department is now in receipt of a letter from Rev. Jos. Anglin, O.M.I., which reads, in part, as follows:

"I have learned that the three grandchildren of Sam Bull of Goodfish Lake were accepted at the Protestant School at Edmonton, although the mother, in dying, asked that they be brought up in the Catholic School. All this confirms my opinion that the Agent at Saddle Lake works for the school at Edmonton, which is not his school, and, on the contrary, does not do a thing for the school of Blue Quills, which is his school. There are even Catholics sent to the Protestant School at Edmonton under the pretext that the parents are asking for it."

The Department would appreciate your taking up this matter with Mr. Agent Gullion, with particular reference to the three grandchildren of Sam Bull. You should ascertain what religion the parents of these three children were recognized as professing and you should state how long they have been residing with Sam Bull.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 118-1-10 of the 23rd instant in connection with the admission of the Grandchildren of Sam Bull of Whitefish Lake Reserve, to the Edmonton Indian Residential School. I note the quotation given from a letter received by the Department from the Principal of Blue Quills School.

I consider that Father Angin's remarks about Mr. Gullion are uncalled for; Our Agent may have many faults but one thing I can say for him is that he is honest and above-board in all his dealings and I know he wishes to be fair to both schools. This is the first intimation I have had that the Catholic Church has any call on the children whatever; Sam Bull, I believe, attended the Red Deer School, although I am not sure of this. One thing I do know is that he is a Protestant, as he is a representative from that part of the country to the annual conference of the United Church in Edmonton and when I was there in May last year, Sam Bull was attending the said conference; and he has always been considered the principal representative of the Protestant Church amongst the Indians in that section. Therefore, as the mother of the children in question was Sam's daughter, and as far as I know they have always lived with him, I presume Sam has the right to say what school they should go to; and as I have said before, I have never had any intimation that there was any question of these children going to anything but a Protestant School. I will, however, write to Mr. Gullion and get full particulars, and advise the Department as soon as I hear from him.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

SIR:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No.407-5 of the 29th ultimo in regard to William G. Erasmus, Beatrice Olive Erasmus and Elmer Charles Erasmus, grandchildren of Sam Bull, recently admitted to the Edmonton Indian Residential school, and I wish to submit the following in reply thereto:

Although I was familiar with the situation insofar as these children were concerned, I have again since the receipt of your letter, interviewed Sam Bull, chiefly in order to ascertain whether or not his daughter had made a last request in connection with having the children placed in any particular school. Sam Bull stated that she had not done so and denied positively, the statement that his daughter's dying wish was that the children were to be brought up in a Catholic school.

Sam Bull and family are and always have been Protestants. The Erasmus family are also all Protestants. Sam Bull has been taking a leading part in matters concerning United Church affairs at the Goodfish Lake mission and has taken services at the church in the absence of the resident missionary. He has also been attending the United Church conferences and district meetings as a delegate representing the Indians of that mission. Sam Bull and his wife both attended the old Red Deer Industrial school for a time and his children have attended the Red Deer Industrial and the Edmonton Indian Residential schools. He has a son, Willie Bull, in the Edmonton Residential school at the present time. His daughter, the late Mrs. L. Erasmus, attended this school and she, like the rest of the family, belonged to the United Church. L. Erasmus and Sam Bull's daughter were married in the United Church at Goodfish Lake.

I would say that Sam Bull is one of the leading

M. Christianson Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate,
Calgary, Alta.
Protestants at Whitefish Lake reserve and as his son-in-law is a Protestant and comes from a Protestant family, there should be no question as to their religion. Excepting during short intervals on a few occasions when the parents were visiting elsewhere, Sam Bull states that he has had these children since infancy.

Questioning Sam Bull as to whether his son-in-law might have asked or written Rev. Father Angin in regard to taking them in his school, he stated that although he did not think that he had, it was possible that L. Erasmus might have made enquiries and that if such were the case, his son-in-law, since he was not keeping the children, should not have done so without first consulting him. I might mention that these children, together with Rena Grace Whitford and Thelma Whitford, were sent to the Edmonton Resident School on the 25th ultimo, Sam Bull acting as their escort.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

Referring to your letter No.118-1-10 of the 22nd ultimo in regard to the subject dealt with in your letters of the 27th October and December 15th last, I beg to submit the following.

In regard to the information received by the Department that a request had been made for the admission of Thomas Houle's children into the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school, I might say that in order to avoid any possible trouble, this question has been dealt with very carefully from the beginning. I have interviewed these people personally and recently when I had occasion to send Farming Instructor Mr. Boorse to Whitefish Lake reserve, I requested him to call and see them in order to ascertain whether or not they had changed their attitude toward the school. They discussed the question with him very much along the same lines as on previous occasions they had discussed it with me. I might mention however that while Mrs. Thomas Houle had taken very little part in the early discussions regarding their children, she had lately apparently intimated that she would have preferred having them in the Blue Quill's school as they would then be nearer home. On the other hand, Thomas Houle still maintains that they should go to the Edmonton Indian Residential school.

Regarding the children of James Houle and Thomas Houle, I would also refer to previous correspondence, namely; my letter dated March 16th, 1931 and official letter No. 110-C-10 dated May 5th, 1931. Also my letter of the 20th January, 1932, with applications for admission. No pressure was brought to bear and the request that the children be placed in the Edmonton Residential school came from the parents voluntarily. Considerable time elapsed between the time the request was first made and the date of the admission of

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
the children to the Edmonton school. This is a matter on which a good deal of time has been spent and the information submitted to the Department concerning these cases was obtained from personal interviews and not from hearsay. The recruiting of Indian children on the reserves here is done by myself with the assistance of the Farming Instructor only. No efforts were made to recruit from the James Houle and Thomas Houle families during the past year.

In regard to these two families, I have endeavored to place before the Department as accurately as possible, information as obtained. Had the parents expressed to me any desire to place their children in the Blue Quill's school, I should have been glad to have placed their request before the Department. This matter will again be taken up with them later and the Department will be fully advised before any action is taken.

Regarding the girl Flora Lewis, I beg to refer to my letter No.215 dated October 8th, 1928 and official letter No.39218-1 dated February 12th, 1929, in reply thereto. As instructed therein, I interviewed the foster parents, Gladu, shortly after the receipt of this letter and advised them that while the Department did not desire to disturb their relationship, it would have to be understood that the child Flora would be placed in a Roman Catholic school when she became of age. The statement made by your informant that I was endeavoring to place this girl in the Edmonton Residential school is not true. As a matter of fact, I was approached by a delegation of Indians at Whitefish Lake reserve last spring regarding this girl. The delegation headed by one Jas. Half, a relative of the girl, stated that they had been told that I had advised Gladu to be prepared to send the child to the Blue Quill's school and that as the foster parents were Protestants, they had discussed the matter and decided to ask me if it would be possible to send the girl to the Edmonton Residential school. I advised them that Gladu had been told that the girl would necessarily have to be sent to a Catholic school and that so far as I was concerned I would have to carry out my instructions. The child was unfit at that time and I advised them that the Department would be asked before anything definite was decided on.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Hamilton
Indian Agent.

Le 12 Mai 1935

À Monsieur A.F. Mackenzie,
Secrétaire du Département des Affaires Indiennes,
Ottawa.

Monsieur,

J'ai reçu il y a déjà quelque temps votre lettre du 17 Avril, No 118-1-10 concernant les petits enfants de Sam Bull, Indien de Goodfish-Lake. Dans ma précédente lettre, j'avais fait allusion à ce fait que la mère de ces enfants avait demandé avant sa mort que ses 5 enfants fussent élevés à l'école Blue Quills dans la religion catholique.

Durant l'hiver dernier, des Indiens de Saddle-Lake ont passé quelque temps à Goodfish Lake pour la pêche et ont assisté aux derniers moments de cette femme, Madame Erasmus, fille de Sam Bull. Ils l'ont entendu exprimer ses dernières volontés au sujet des susdits enfants, et sont venus à différentes reprises me demander d'accepter dans mon école ces enfants. Je leur ai répondu que ces enfants étant métis ne pouvaient être acceptés dans une école indienne sans la permission du Département Indien et sans l'acceptation de l'Agent. Ces Indiens sont donc venus ici sans intérêt de leur part et j'ai cru à leur parole, d'où l'allusion dans ma lettre. Depuis j'ai reçu votre lettre et le rapport fait à vous sans aucun doute par l'Agent Gullion. J'ai revu et questionné à nouveau ces 5 Indiens en leur lisant même une partie du rapport de Gullion et ils ont été indignés. Dans le rapport en effet, il est dit que Sam Bull a interrogé sur les dernières volontés de sa fille, a nié positivement que cette dernière ait eu la volonté de faire éduquer ses enfants dans une école catholique.

J'ai donc interroger ces 5 Indiens, Robert Houle, Lazarus Shirt, et Joseph Houle et sur leur désir je leur ai fait signer les affidavits que vous trouverez inclus. Ils ont entendu Madame Erasmus et témoignent qu'elle a demandé à son père Sam Bull que ses 5 enfants soient éduqués dans une école catholique et baptisées catholiques. Contre ce fait, vous ne pouvez rien et Gullion qui fait l'apologie des Bull écrit en marge du fait.

Il s'agit de savoir maintenant qui ment, ou bien Sam Bull ou bien l'Agent Gullion. Les Indiens ci-dessus nommés accusent Gullion, et je n'en serais pas étonné, ce ne serait pas d'ailleurs la première fois qu'il ferait un faux rapport, j'en ai la preuve.

Je vais continuer mon enquête à ce sujet pour savoir qui a menti. En tout cas, vous avez les affidavits au nombre de 3, si vous en voulez d'autres, je peux vous en procurer, car nombreux sont ceux qui ont entendu la fille de Sam Bull émettre ses dernières volontés au sujet de ses enfants.

L'affaire n'est donc pas encore finie.

Poville, agent, Monsieur, une salutation,

Rev. J. Angus, Provincial
Sir,

I have received sometime ago your letter of the 17th of April No. 118-1-10 concerning the grand children of Sam Bull, Indian of Goldfish Lake. In my preceding letter I hinted to the fact that the mother of these children had asked before her death that her 3 children be brought up at the Blue Quills school in the catholic religion.

During last Winter, some Indians of Saddle Lake have remained sometime at Goldfish Lake for fishing and were present at the last moments of this woman, Mrs. Erdman's daughter of Sam Bull. They heard her express her last will in regard to the above mentioned children, and came at different occasions back me to accept in my school. I replied that these children were half-breeds and could not be accepted in an Indian school without permission from the Department and the approval of the Agent. These Indians have consequently come here without interest on their part and I took their word that was alluded to in my letter. Since then I have received your letter and the report made to you no doubt by Agent Gullion. I saw again and questioned those three Indians and read them part of the report of Gullion and they were indignantly over it. In fact in the report it is said that Sam Bull being interrogated over the last wishes of his daughter, has positively denied that the latter had had the desire of having her children educated.
in a catholic school.

Consequently questioned these 3 Indians, Robert Houle, James Short and Joseph Houle and upon their request I had them sign the affidavits attached herewith. They heard Mrs. Graham and testify that she asked her father Sam Bull that her three children be educated in a catholic school and baptised as catholics. Against these facts you can not do anything and Gullion who stands as the vindicator of the Bull wrote in contradiction of the facts.

The question is to know now who lies, whether it is Sam Bull or Agent Gullion. The above mentioned Indians accuse Gullion, and I would not be surprised if it was not the first time he would make a false report. I have the proof of it.

I will continue my investigation over this matter to find out who lied. However you have the affidavits, this of them if you wish for more, I can get you them because there are many who hear the daughters of Sam Bull express her last wishes about her children.

This matter is consequently not yet closed.

Kindly accept, Sir, my best regards,

[Signature]

To Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Bureau of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to ask you that the children of Thomas Houle of Goodfish Lake be placed at the Blue Quills School. There has been a long correspondence last year about this case, and would be pleased to get a decision.

I get you remember that Thomas Houle has been baptised catholic before his marriage with a catholic woman, and promised at this time that all his children would be baptised catholics. In fact, they have been baptised in catholic religion. Four years ago, I asked to the Department that some of these children be admitted into Blue Quills School, and I received a reply from Mr Ferrier, letter No 110-0-10, of May 5th 1931, stating that the choice of the school should be given to Thomas Houle. I do not know what orders received Indian Agent Gullion at this time, but I know that Thomas Houle was not given the choice as to the school where he should place his children. He was said by the Indian Agent: "There is place at Edmonton School for your children, you have to send them there". In fact one boy was sent to Edmonton School but did not stay long. Last year, Thomas Houle asked me to take another boy to my school, and this year he has repeated his asking for 2 boys. More of that, he has advised Mr Gullion that he would place his children at Blue Quills School.

As you see, this case is under question since long time, and I guess it is reasonable to ask for a decision. These children have been baptised catholics, they have never been baptised protestants, and I have the right to ask that they be admitted into Blue Quills school.

Hoping you take the case in consideration and you give finally a decision, I remain,

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
Ottawa, August 28th, 1935.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to your F-85 of April 12th, last, and previous correspondence with reference to the children of Thomas Houle.

The Department is in receipt of another letter, urging the admission of these children to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. We are, also, informed that Houle has advised you that he wishes his children placed in the Blue Quills School.

Please make immediate inquiries and advise the Department if Houle and his wife are now recognized as Catholics. We are definitely informed that all the children have been baptized Catholics. If Houle is now recognized as a Catholic, there is no reason why his children should not be placed in the Blue Quills School. The Department will expect you to give this matter your immediate attention and forward your report by September 14th.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No.118-1-10 of the 28th ultimo in regard to the children of Thomas Houle. In reply, I might say that I interviewed Thomas Houle after treaty payments in July and on the 7th August regarding his children and I again saw him on the 3rd instant. He makes no definite statement in the matter of his religion, apparently giving the matter very little, if any, serious consideration. He however stated on the last two occasions when the question was discussed, that he would like to place the two boys now at home, Robert - age 13 years and Alex. Houle - age 10 years, in the Blue Quill's Residential school, the reason given when discussing the subject being, that the children would be nearer home and that he could see them conveniently should they become sick at any time.

In regard to religion professed by Thomas Houle, I beg to refer to my letter of the 16th March 1931. There is no apparent change in his attitude as reported at that time. Mrs. Thomas Houle is a Roman Catholic. As you are aware, there are two children from this family in the Edmonton Residential school. Houle states that he does not wish to disturb these but he would now like to place the two boys above mentioned in the Blue Quill's Residential school. If the Department approves, Houle will be advised that these two boys should be placed in the Blue Quill's school.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Guildon
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 10, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your telegram of the 9th instant, with reference to the children who have not returned to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School after the holidays.

It is noted that you have directed the parents to take the children back to the school. Have you ascertained recently whether or not they have carried out your instructions in this regard? The Department considers that all pupils allowed out on holidays should have returned to the school by this time.

The Department will expect you to give this matter your immediate attention and make absolutely certain that the children have returned to the Blue Quills Residential School. It is hoped that the letter which you state you are forwarding will include full explanations regarding the reasons for the children from the Beaver Lake Reserve not returning to the school.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.
Ottawa, November 16, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of letter from Dr. Decosse dated the 4th instant which reads, in part, as follows:

"I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter file No. 115-1-13 and must say that I am surprised to hear that the children had not all returned to school by October 15th.

I completed an inspection of all the children actually on the reserve on September 15th and advised Mr. Gullion two days afterwards that all the children with a few exceptions could return to school. The latter were cases who had not had pertussis and were coughing at the time, and the parents were advised to keep them home for a week or more and that if the cough ceased, they were to be sent to school, if not, they were to report to the Agent who was to advise me so that they could be re-examined. As none of these cases reported I assumed that they only had a cold of the ordinary variety and that all had returned to school before October 1st."

It would appear from the above that Dr. Decosse expected the children to return to the Blue Quills Residential School much sooner than they did. The Department has not yet received the letter which you stated in your telegram of the 9th instant you were forwarding. It is hoped, however, when this letter is received, that it will explain why you did not make certain that the pupils had returned to the Blue Quills School about September 17th, which was the date Dr. Decosse informed you that the majority of them could return.

Yours truly,

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.

Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

J.M. Quinn
Lazare Bearskin

You wrote to Rev. Nathan Langlois that orders had been given to have these children back to school; you can see by yourself that the orders have not been put to execution; and I am not so much surprised myself as Gullion is just good for nothing. It would be as well as to put a wood stick as agent instead of Gullion, but with this difference that a wood stick would cost nothing to the Government, whilst Gullion costs $1000.00 of salary per year. And in a few months, Gullion will retire with a pension, and the poor workers of Canada will be obliged to sweat over their work to earn money to pay taxes for giving a pension to this fellow. This is absolutely a shame. And this should be put in the papers; I don't say that sometimes I will not write this case in the papers, chiefly as I know that Gullion did not watch over his clerk Sicard who stole $450.00 from the purse of the Agency 2 years ago.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

September 23rd, 1937.

Sir:-

I wish to submit the following for your consideration and advice:-

On the 13th instant, having been informed that one Belrose (Wm.) Norwest, non-treaty French half-breed, had arrived on the Saddle Lake reserve, I warned him in writing to leave the reserve at once and that upon his failure to do so, action would be taken in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Act. Norwest disappeared from the place at which he was staying but four or five days later, he turned up at another place on the reserve.

Discussing this and other matters with the R.C.M.P. Police at St. Paul, I was informed that a complaint had been made to the effect that this man had deserted his family of six children near Frog Lake Indian Reserve. The names and the ages of the children were given by the Police as follows:-

| Name       | Age |
|------------|-----|
| Louis      | 13  |
| Mary Emma  | 10  |
| Josephine  | 8   |
| Julia      | 6   |
| Alvina     | 4   |
| Floyd Edward | 2  |

They were said to have been living on Section 2, Township 56, Range 3, West of the 4th meridian. This matter had been taken up with the Provincial authorities and the R.C.M.P. Police were evidently instructed to refer the case to the Indian Agent, Saddle Lake Agency.

On the 21st instant, I issued a warrant to apprehend Belrose (Wm.) Norwest on a charge of trespass. In the meantime, he had again disappeared and upon making enquiries, I found that he had brought his children to the reserve.

reserves, leaving three of them with an Indian woman, Mrs. Kakeseem of No.25, Blue Quill's Band No.127. Mrs. Kakeseem's daughter Cecile was the common law wife of Belrose (Wm.) Norwest and the mother of the children. She died last Spring.

When I called at the Blue Quill's school on Tuesday, I was informed that Mrs. Kakeseem had taken there, three of the children, namely,- Louis, Mary Emma and Julia Norwest. These children are now at this school. The other three children are likely in the hands of Norwest who has not been located since the issuance of warrant.

When asked regarding the status of these children, I stated that according to the Indian Act, in my opinion, these children were not wards of the Department of Indian Affairs and that under the circumstances, I could not make any recommendation in the matter of having them cared for by the Department.

The grandmother, Mrs. Kakeseem, is an elderly woman (widow) and receives rations and she could not keep any of the children without extra assistance.

I should be glad to have your advice in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

I beg to report on a visit of inspection I made to Beaver Lake and Whitefish Lake Reserves in the Saddle Lake Agency, during the month of December, last.

Beaver Lake

There is no school on this reserve. The children are sent to Blue Quills and Edmonton Indian Residential schools. I found that sufficient attention has not been given to children returning to school after the summer vacation. Likewise, there is a number of children of school age who are not attending school. Again the cause is lack of supervision.

Dear Sir:

I regret to inform you that we were obliged to take Madeleine Lapatack back to the Blue Quills School. She was taking Grade IX at St. Paul School and became discouraged as she could not keep up with the class. The other girl, Josephine Paskweyak, still continues in Grade IX.

As Madeleine had met any hope to go to she wished to come back here. Therefore, with your permission I will keep her name on the roll until the end of the year.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Balter, O.M.I.
Principal

Sir:—

Referring to your letter No.118-1-10 of the 18th instant in regard to the application for admission of Jenny Cardinal into the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school, I wish to inform you that the mother of this child is a treaty Indian woman of this agency. The father, Henry Cardinal, is a non-treaty Indian, originally from Onion Lake reserve, later moving to and residing on the Saddle Lake reserve.

Upon checking over this file, I note that in replying to letter of Agent J.F. Pugh, dated February 7th, 1924, the Department by official letter No.62-118 dated February 14th, 1924, approved of the admission of Henry Cardinal into membership in the Saddle Lake Band. The instructions given therein regarding Cardinal, were however, rescinded by official letter No.62-118 dated May 16th, 1924, and Cardinal was therefore not taken in as a member.

The children of this family have lived the Indian mode of life on reserves since infancy and admissions of pupil No.0254—Flora Cardinal, and No.277—Arsene Cardinal, now in Blue Quill's Residential school were approved by the Department. These are children of the same family and although they are not in treaty, they are Indians and as such, are considered eligible for admission.

Your obedient servant,

" 501 Lens Noel; I wish to inform you that these children, also No. 500, Blanche McFeeters, are from Onion Lake Agency and I am attaching herewith copy of letter which I have today addressed to Dr. J.T. Hill regarding the forms.

In regard to No. 502 Miles Hunter, the members of this family are Protestants and there are two pupils now in the Edmonton Indian Residential school. Miles Hunter's parents, Cleophas Hunter and Louise Hunter (formerly Louise Quinnie of No.100-Band 125) of No.220 James Seenum's Band No.128, are Protestants and come from Protestant families. I have the application for admission of Miles Hunter but it is not signed by the father. Hunter happened to be absent on each of my visits to Whitefish Lake reserve and I have not to date been able to get an explanation as to why this boy was taken to the Blue Quill's school. However, this will be done at the first opportunity.

While dealing with the subject, I should also like to mention the cases of Thos. Jackson and Reuben Bull, both of Whitefish Lake reserve. Thos. Jackson has on two or three occasions asked to have his children transferred from the Edmonton Residential school to the Blue Quill's Residential school.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Reuben Bull has children enrolled at the Edmonton Residential school and when I called during a check up of children to be returned to the schools after holidays, they were preparing to send a younger girl to the Blue Quill's school in the school truck which had been sent out for the children. I advised them that they could not do this and as the child had become ill in the meantime, she was kept at home. His explanation was that his older girl had been sick when sent home for holidays and that he was dissatisfied for various reasons. He also mentioned that although he was a Protestant, his wife was a Roman Catholic and for this reason, he considered that if they so desired, they should be permitted to place a child in the Blue Quill's school.

I explained the regulations and I am mentioning these cases merely to advise the Department of the attitude of some of the Indian parents in the matter of placing children in schools.

Your obedient servant,

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School shows that pupil No. 226, Ernest Crane, is over the age of 16.

No application for retaining this boy in your school appears to have been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. L. Balter, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
St. Paul, Alta.
I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupils mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith, report respecting the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School for the month of March, 1940.

I might mention that while discussing matters concerning the school, the Reverend Principal mentioned that he had received instructions to the effect that pupils who had reached the age of 16 years should be discharged.

While there are a few who are 16 years old on the roll, the Reverend Principal would like to have them in school until the end of the current term. A number of others shall have reached the age of 16 years by that time and the discharge of those who have reached this age would then be asked for at the end of the school term.

Occasionally, a boy or girl wishes to remain in school after they reach the age of 16 years and in cases such as these, it would appear to be regrettable to have to discharge them. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant with reference to the March quarter return of the Blue Quills Residential School.

The Principal was written recently regarding children 16 years of age or over in the school. We have no objection to these pupils remaining in the school until the end of the current academic year; namely, June 30 next.

However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing, and the further consideration that due to conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupils at residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

However, if there are a few pupils who you consider should remain in the Blue Quills Residential School after they reach the age of 16 you should communicate with the Department stating your reasons.

Mr. W. A. Gullion,
Indian Agent,
Head Lake, Alta.
and making a definite recommendation. The point to emphasize is that no pupils over 16 years of age should be kept in the Blue Quills Residential School after June 30 next unless the approval of the Department has been obtained. Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith for consideration and advice, certificate of health and application for admission of Allan Hunter into the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School.

This boy is a son of Norman Hunter of No.239 of James Seenum's Band No.126. This has been known as a Protestant family but Hunter refused to send his children to the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

In November, 1939, Hunter placed this boy, voluntarily, in the Blue Quill's Residential School. He was advised that the boy, being a Protestant, was not eligible for admission to that school. He insisted that he wanted his boy to remain in the Blue Quill's school and on the 2nd December, 1939, signed an application for admission form. On the 22nd February, 1940, the mother, Mrs. Norman Hunter, took this boy and his sister Annie (who had also been placed in this school) home. On the 23rd April, 1940, Norman Hunter called the Reverend Principal by phone from Spenden and asked why his children had been sent home. He also informed the Reverend Principal that he was sending his children back to the school by train and that he wished Reverend Father Balter to meet them. This was done and the boy Allan has since remained in the Blue Quill's school.

The parents requested that their children be brought up in the Roman Catholic faith and Reverend Father Balter states that complying with their request, he baptized Allan on the 19th May, 1940. The father, Norman Hunter, was interviewed on several occasions in regard to his children but there has been no change in his attitude toward the Edmonton Residential School.

In view of the circumstances in the case, I have not signed the application form as I consider that I should not be justified in making any recommendation before obtaining the opinion of the Department in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Guillon
Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs:

I send you herewith a copy of a letter just received from Mr. J. H. Boorse "Acting Indian Agent" Saddle Lake Alta., and my answer to Him.

In this letter he says: "Word has just been received from Ottawa." As he does not give any name, I am writing to you directly asking you to be kind enough to communicate its contents to the Indian department, Ottawa.

In the letter from Ottawa, it is said: "The father of this boy Allan Hunter, is still recognized as a Protestant" but the fact that Mr. Norman Hunter has placed his children in a Catholic School, consenting that they become Catholics if they so desire, and be baptized, goes to show, that he is not a disbeliever in the Catholic religion, but rather belongs to that category of people who put the Protestant and the Catholic Religion on the same level, with rather a tendency in favor of the Catholic Church, and want to be free to send their children in the School of their own choice.

I don't know what is the intention of the Indian Act. But I suppose it is not the intention of the Indian Act to go against the Natural Law which gives the parents the right to have their children instructed and educated in the school of their own choice.

We did not take any steps to have those people bring their child in our school. The child was brought here by his own mother and the father of the child before two witnesses Mr. Jonas Cardinal and Lloyd Cardinal signed a statement saying that he freely agreed that his son become a Catholic and be baptized if and when he desired so. This document has been sent to the Indian Department long ago. The child after instruction has asked to be received in the Church. The child thus having been baptized with the consent of his father, having made his first communion and having been confirmed, belongs to the Catholic Church and therefore being a Roman Catholic Child, his place is here in the Blue Quills School which is a Roman Catholic School, according to the spirit and the letter of the Indian Act.

Is it not for the survival of a true Democracy, the freedom of the people that the whole British Empire and her Allies are fighting for? and if the father of a family has not the right and is not free to put his child in the school of his own choice, then what would such a Democracy amount to? Another remark may be made: During the holydays Mr. Hunter and his family assist at the Catholic Service in the Catholic Church whenever the Missionary is visiting the reserve. If those people were really disbelievers in the Catholic religion, they would not act that way. In conclusion, I once more make application for the admission of Allan Hunter, a Roman Catholic Child, in the Blue Quills Roman Catholic Residential School at St. Paul. Yours very truly,

(Signed) "L. BALTER," C.M.I., Prin.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo enclosing copy of letter received from Rev. L. Balter, O.M.I., Principal of the Blue Quills Residential School, with reference to the admission of three children of Norman Hunter to that school.

In order to carry out the intention of the Indian Act the Department has generally considered that a Catholic child is one whose parents are recognized as Catholics, and that a Protestant child is one whose parents are recognized as Protestants.

It is evident from the contents of Father Balter's letter that he wishes to place a different interpretation on the matter of eligibility for admission to a residential school. In other words, he desires that parents, either Catholic or Protestant, be permitted to designate the religion in which they wish their children educated. The Department has very carefully considered this suggestion of the Principal and as yet is not in a position to make a final decision. Our experience shows, however, that the recognition of the principle suggested by Father Balter would, in all probability, lead to a great deal of embarrassment to both Principals of residential schools and all others interested in education. If we admit the principle advocated by Father Balter in one case there is no reason why it should not be admitted in others. Besides, if a parent decides to have his child placed in a residential school on the first of September and then changes his mind on the first of December there

Mr. C.P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.
would be no reason why we should not accept his wishes and, in that event, you can easily see that there is a great probability that parents would shift their children from schools of one religious denomination to another unless they obtained all the privileges to which they might consider themselves entitled.

Our information indicates that the Hunter family has always been recognized as Protestant and as you are aware the older children of this family were placed, at one time, at the request of the parents, in the Edmonton Residential School.

Before making a decision on Father Balter's request I should appreciate it if you would again communicate with him or, better still, if you expect to be in the vicinity of the Blue Quills School in the near future it would be preferable if you would personally interview him and discuss the whole situation with him.

There is another matter which should be brought to the Principal's attention; namely, that instructions have been repeatedly issued to Principals of all residential schools to the effect that pupils whose religious eligibility is not certain must not be admitted to a residential school until the Department's decision has been given. In the present instance Father Balter has totally disregarded these instructions. Besides, information received by the Department indicates that there is no scarcity of recruits in any part of the Dominion for residential schools. Consequently, it is difficult to see why any Principal should not confine his efforts to those eligible for admission. As you are aware, in too many cases Indians develop grievances against a Principal of a residential school and as a consequence they think they can punish that Principal by requesting the admission of their children to a school conducted under different religious auspices from those which they themselves practice.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In a recent letter received from Father Balter, principal of the Blue Quills School at St. Paul, Alta., the case is brought to me of young Allan Hunter whom the Indian Department has requested be sent back to his father. This decision of the Department is, in my opinion, in direct violation of the Indian Act that specifies that Catholic children shall be sent to Catholic schools, and undoubtedly this child has been baptized a Catholic. Moreover, it is the inherent right of parents to send their children to the school of their choice—a right that is not sufficiently safeguarded by the Indian Act, and in this the Indian Act, in my opinion should be amended. To deny this to Indians savours too much of unjust oppression such as we are presently combatting in Europe; it is in direct violation of that religious liberty for which Mr. Roosevelt stands in his recent speech. Moreover, the cases of Indian children who had been baptized Catholics but put in Protestant schools have been brought to me in at least four cases. In these cases the parents wanted them brought up in the Protestant schools and I could oppose no just objection because I have always thought it the natural right of parents to choose their school. I believe that in the case of Allan Hunter, the same right of parents should prevail.

With every good wish for the New Year, I remain,

Dear Father Routhier:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 7th instant in which you discuss the desirability of having an Indian pupil, Allan Hunter, enrolled for instruction at the Blue Quills Residential School.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a letter relating to this matter sent forward to Inspector Schmidt a few days ago. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

It would appear that the policy of the Department for a number of years has been to look upon a Catholic child as the child of Catholic parents, and a non-Catholic child as the child of non-Catholic parents. This interpretation appears to have been satisfactory to the Church authorities until now. If, however, the new interpretation suggested by the Principal of the Blue Quills School were acceptable to all the Churches I feel confident the Government would be glad to review the whole matter. My personal opinion is that this new interpretation would create difficulties for the Principals of our residential schools that would prove almost insurmountable. In other words, the Indian parent dissatisfied with the treatment of his children at a particular school, or cherishing real or imaginary grievances, would immediately ask for the transfer of his children to the nearest residential school operated under the auspices of another Church.

Rev. H. Routhier, O.M.I.,
9916 110th Street,
Edmonton, Alta.
This whole matter is still under review and it is my intention to discuss the matter with Rev. Father Plourde during one of his periodical visits to Ottawa. In the meantime it is of the utmost importance that no misunderstanding should exist with respect to the rights of Indian parents. There are few nationals anywhere in the world that enjoy greater freedom with respect to the education of their children than the citizens of Canada. We must be careful to bear in mind, however, that Indians are not citizens in the sense that we usually speak of citizens. Indians are wards of the Government and in a legal sense are minors. It can readily be seen, therefore, that the wards of a government are subject to all the limitations that wardship implies. I emphasize this because I note that the Principal of the Blue Quills Residential School, in his letter to Inspector Schmidt, discusses the rights of parents as if Indians enjoyed the full rights, advantages and privileges of full democratic citizenship. Indians can enjoy these rights, of course, by enfranchisement for which provision is made in the Indian Act.

May I embrace this opportunity to wish you and your associates a very happy and prosperous New Year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I thank you for your letter of January 14, and particularly for the New Year greetings.

Re "If the new interpretation suggested by the principal of the Blue Quills School were acceptable to all the Churches, I feel confident the Government would be glad to review the whole matter." I believe definitely that in recent years this has been the policy of the Department and the Churches have not given another interpretation. I remember some two years ago the case of three children from the Wabamun Reserve, baptized Catholics, and of Catholic parents who had died, who were entrusted to Protestant guardians and placed in the Protestant school of Morley. I had thought this unusual and having referred the case to Father Plourde, he told me that children were placed mainly according to the wishes of the parents or guardians. I have for reference also the case of Albert Cardinal of the Saddle Lake Reserve, baptized Catholic, born of Catholic parents, his father being Baptiste Cardinal, who was sent to the Protestant school of Edmonton and remained there throughout his schooling. This Baptiste Cardinal has now two of his children at the Blue Quills School. I have no doubt, but I know well that Father Riou has told me more than once that some of his Catholic parents sent their children to the Protestant school at the Blackfoot Reserve.

I realize well that the Indians should not be allowed, for imaginary grievances, to transfer their children, especially during the school year, from one institution to another, and this can easily be checked, but there is a broad margin from this to not permitting them to place them in the school of their choice when they decide to send their children to school. I understand that Indians are wards of the Government, but no guardian, even though it be the Government, may violate the fundamental rights of persons under its tutelage, although I readily admit that it can fix certain limitations in view of the common good of its subjects, especially where abuse creeps in. I think however that there is far less danger than anywhere else, in allowing Indian parents to choose their school, on account of that deep parental love innate in the human heart, which normally inclines them to follow what they think best for their children.

With regard to Father Balter, may I state that he had no doubts whatever as to the eligibility of Allan Hunter for the Blue Quills School, because Allan had been received into the Church with the consent of his parents and from pressure of ours. Moreover you are most probably acquainted with the utter negligence in some instances of the Galettes in sending the forms to Ottawa for acceptance of pupils.

I feel in all this that there is need of stressing on the freedom of religious belief and instruction for Indians as well as for citizens who have all the benefits of democratic institutions. I would not for any consideration wish to insinuate that there has been infirmity, but I think there has been a certain amount of inconsistency at times in accepting or refusing pupils for certain schools.

I have not yet met Mr. Schmidt - I imagine that he may have been busy with the problem of water at Cardston - but would be glad of the opportunity of seeing him when he goes to St. Paul.

May I offer my most cordial greetings to you, Mr. Hoey, and assure you of our confidence.

Yours Sincerely,

Feb. 1, 1941.

The Hon. Mr. Crerar,

Re Allan Hunter.

I regret to have to write you regarding this matter; but similar cases occur from time to time, causing considerable discontent among those concerned. I knew nothing of this case till a few days ago.

The parents of Allan Hunter are both Protestant Indians, living in the vicinity of what is called the Blue Quills School, a residential school for Indian children in this province. They asked the Oblate Fathers in charge of this school to accept their boy; but the Fathers refused on the ground that children of Protestant parents were supposed to attend their own school. The parents persisted in their demand, and the boy was finally accepted. They went further, asking to have their boy instructed in the Catholic religion, which after much hesitation, the Fathers in charge finally did. Recently, the Fathers in charge were ordered to return the child to his parents on the ground that he has no right to be in that school.

I regret very much the decision of the Indian Agent, Mr. J.H. Rees, in this case. The rule that Catholic and Protestant children should attend their respective schools, and that the religion of children should be determined by that of their parents, works well, generally speaking; perhaps better than any other rule that could be devised; but there have been occasional exceptions that could have aroused bitterness among the Indians had not the Oblate Fathers settled them on the broad basis of common sense. Not long ago, Father Balter tells me, children of Catholic parents were admitted to the Edmonton Schools; but knowing the circumstances, he decided that more good could be done by ignoring the case altogether. I realize that while wards of the Government, Indians have not the rights of ordinary citizens; but they have certain natural rights as parents which should not be denied them altogether, much as they may be circumscribed for good and sufficient reasons; and in cases like the present, I feel that it would be better for all concerned if this boy were permitted to attend the school of his parents choice.

With best wishes, I remain,

Yours very faithfully,

sgd) J.H. MacDonald

Archbishop of Edmonton.

My dear Archbishop Macdonald:

I have for acknowledgment Your Excellency's letter of February 1, in which you discuss the eligibility of Allan Hunter for enrolment at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

It would appear that there is a regulation in force, with respect to the administration and operation of residential schools, whereby the principal of a school is not permitted to enroll a pupil where the religious status of the pupil is in dispute. In such cases the Indian agent and the principal are expected to send forward, for the consideration of the officials, all the facts relating to the case. This particular regulation appears to have been overlooked in the case of Allan Hunter, and this fact explains why the Principal of the Blue Quills School was requested by the Indian agent to return Allan Hunter to his parents.

Section 13 of the Indian Act provides that no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to, or enrolled at, a Protestant school, and that no Protestant child shall be assigned to, or enrolled at, a Roman Catholic school. In practice, it would appear that a Roman Catholic child has been defined as the child of Catholic parents and a non-Catholic child as the child of non-Catholic parents. This definition

Most Reverend J. B. Macdonald, D.D.,
Archbishop of Edmonton,
10544 - 113th Street,
Edmonton, Alberta.
or understanding of what constitutes a Catholic child has on the whole worked out, with rare exceptions, to the satisfaction of all people concerned. In view of this fact, the Department naturally hesitates to depart from this interpretation. The officials are disposed to think that a departure such as the one suggested in the case of Allan Hunter would lead to almost insurmountable difficulties from the standpoint of administration. Indian parents frequently develop a strong dislike of the school principal, and investigation has proved that these dislikes or prejudices are wholly unfounded. However, if the Indian parent had the right to transfer his child from one institution to another when he developed a real or imaginary grievance against the principal, the task of administering our residential schools would become an exceedingly difficult one.

You will be interested to learn that the case of Allan Hunter has been discussed with the Inspector of Indian Agencies for Alberta, Mr. C. F. Schmidt, of Calgary. Mr. Schmidt was instructed by the Department, in a letter dated January 5, 1941, to visit the Blue Quills School and to discuss this case thoroughly with the Principal. In that letter the Inspector was informed that no action would be taken in respect to the case of Allan Hunter until the Inspector himself had visited the school and reported on the matter. I have just learned, however, that Inspector Schmidt has been ill and confined to bed and consequently unable to undertake this task.

This case has also been discussed by the officials with the Reverend Father Plourde, who visited the Department a few days ago. Father Plourde is fully conscious of the difficulties confronting the officials of the Training Division in reaching a decision on this case. He has expressed a desire to have an opportunity to discuss the case and the principle involved with the members of his Indian Missionary Committee.

It is scarcely necessary to add that should the representatives of the churches co-operating
with the Department in the operation of residential schools reach the conclusion that a different interpretation should be put on Section 10 of the Indian Act from the interpretation put upon it until now, the request would be very sympathetically considered by the Department. I have personally no desire whatever - and in this regard I feel that I can speak for the officials of the Department - to reach a decision other than a decision that will safeguard to the utmost extent possible the religious rights of Indian pupils while at the same time rendering the administration of our schools free from the misunderstanding and friction that is likely to arise from time to time when these somewhat unusual cases come up for consideration.

I appreciate your interest in this case and it is my intention to instruct Inspector Schmidt to discuss the matter with you, personally, immediately following his investigation of the case, which, I trust, he will be able to undertake in the course of a few days.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have the honour to inform you that representations have been made to the Department to the effect that in some places there has been a failure on the part of Agents and Employees to abstain from discrimination with regard to the treatment of and attitude towards missions and schools of various denominations and Indians belonging to same.

It is therefore thought well to remind you that this Department insists upon strict neutrality being maintained by its Officers and Employees with regard to religious matters, and will not tolerate any difference of treatment based directly or indirectly upon denominational prejudice.

Great care must be exercised to avoid anything likely to be construed into an attempt to bring pressure to bear upon parents of one denomination to send their children to a school of another, even should such other be the only available one.

No children should be received into any Industrial or Boarding School conducted under any Denomination other than that to which the parents of such children belong, without the express consent of the latter, which it would be prudent to have given in writing, and every such admission made under the sanction of the parents, should be reported to me at the time, with full particulars of the case.

Should a claim be made, at any time after admission, to a pupil, by another denomination, the facts must be promptly and fully reported to me.

I would further remind you that Missionaries of all Denominations should have perfect liberty to exercise their ministry among the Indians, whether Denominational or Infidel, and any application to construct Church or Missionary buildings should be transmitted to me, together with a statement as to whether the Indians concerned are agreeable to such application being granted or not.

I have, etc.
