Calgary, March 22nd, 1941.

Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your No. 118-1-10 dated January 3rd, last, re admission to the Blue Quills Residential School, of Annie, John and Allan, three children of Norman Hunter, No. 239, James Seenum's Band, Saddle Lake Agency; also your letter, even number, dated the 26th ultimo, with enclosure, re Allan Hunter mentioned above. In reply I beg to say that when at Saddle Lake Agency and Blue Quills School last week, I discussed the matter fully with Rev. L. Balter, the Principal.

As there have been several letters written regarding these admissions, it might be well to review the matter briefly:

On December 2nd, 1939, Mrs. Norman Hunter brought three of their children, viz., Annie - aged about 14 years, John - aged about 12 years, and Allan - aged about 11 years, to the Blue Quills School, and asked the Principal to admit them.

Note: (In his letter No. 95, dated November 25, 1940, Agent Gullion gives this date as November, 1939, and states that the "parents" brought the children.) The Rev. Principal states that it was on December 2nd, that the mother only came, and that he then took the information required on the application forms, but refused to have the mother sign same, telling her these would have to be signed by the father, as he understood both she and her husband were Protestants. The mother insisted that he accept the children, left them there, and went home.

On January 15th, 1940, (Note: Agent Gullion in his letter gives the date as December 2nd, 1939; the Principal says it was on January 15th,) Norman Hunter, the father, came to the School, and insisted that the Principal admit the three children, and there and then signed the applications which had been prepared on December 2nd. The Principal says that he forgot to change the date to January 15th. Hunter also signed a statement -- or declaration -- whereby he agreed, that his three children be baptized and become Roman Catholics if they (the children) so desired. Both documents were signed in the presence of, and witnessed by James Cardinal, R.M., and Lloyd Cardinal, members of Saddle Lake Band. Hunter then went home, leaving the children at the School.

On February 22nd, 1940, the mother came back to visit, and when about to leave, told the Principal she was lonesome and wished to bring the children home. The Principal replied: "Your children are not enrolled; you are free to bring them with you," which she did.

In April, 1940, Hunter phoned the Principal from Spedden -- a village on the C.N.R. -- wanting to know why his children had been sent home. He was told that his wife had said she wanted to bring them home, and that she had been informed she could do so as they were not enrolled. Hunter then said to the Principal: "I left my children at your School, and I want them admitted to that School. I am sending them by train to St. Paul, and ask you to meet them there." The Principal told Hunter he would not

The Secretary,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.
take John into the School, as the Doctor had said he had a weak chest. Annie and Allan were sent to St. Paul by train, and met there by the School rig.

At the School, Annie and Allan followed the same routine and course of studies — academic and religious — as the other pupils. Early in May, both children went to the Principal and asked to be baptized Roman Catholics. Having the parents' consent, and that of the father in writing, the Principal baptized them on the 19th day of May, 1940, after which he sent the application for admission forms to the Agent, together with a declaration signed by himself, stating that they had been baptized; also a copy of the statement signed by the father, agreeing and authorizing that this be done, if the children so wished. These were received at the Agency office and held there. When at the Agency in November, last, I visited the School with Agent Gullion, and the Principal enquired of the Agent whether the admissions had been approved by the Department, adding: "It is some time since you told me you had sent them." When at the Agency office the next day, I enquired into this matter, and the applications were found on the file in the filing cabinet. The Agent had no reason to give for not having forwarded them to the Department. He then wrote his letter No. 95, dated November 25th, re Annie Hunter, copy of which I forwarded to the Department with my No. 403-11A.U. of December 24th, 1940; also his No. 85 of the same date, re Allan Hunter.

Both Annie and Allan went home for the Summer vacation, 1940, and when the School truck passed through the reserve to pick up the pupils and bring them back for the reopening of school for the fall term, they were brought to the roadway by their mother, who saw them get on the truck.

Norman Hunter and his wife, nee Eva Half, are looked upon as Protestants. Rev. Father Balter states that they attend the Roman Catholic services with their family during the holidays: (Ref. his letter, Dec. 18th, 1940, Page 1, last paragraph).

Re the older children having been placed in the Edmonton School at the request of the parents: (Ref. Dept. letter No. 118-1-10 dated January 3rd, 1940). From information I gathered at the agency office, an application for admission form for Howard Hunter, aged 10 years, dated August 15th, 1933, unsigned by the father and bearing the notation, "Refused to sign," was forwarded to the Department by Agent Gullion, under cover of his letter dated October 15th, 1933, which letter also states that the parents refuse to sign. Application for admission form for Annie Hunter, aged 11 years, dated October 1st, 1936, also unsigned and bearing the notation: "Refused to sign," was forwarded to the Department by Agent Gullion under cover of his letter No. 95, dated November 12th, 1940, which letter also states that the parents refuse to sign. The physical examination form in both these cases had been signed by Dr. G.J. Williamson, M.D. How long Howard remained in school I cannot ascertain from Agency records. Annie did not return after the June term of 1939. (Ref. Agent Gullion's letter No. 95 of Nov. 25th, attached to my No. 403-11A.U. of December 24th, 1940). It will be noted that in this letter also, the Agent states that the parents refused to sign the application for admission. I do not find any information at the office to show whether Annie attended school in 1937-38.
The instructions issued to Principals to the effect that pupils whose religious eligibility is not certain must not be admitted to a residential school until the Department's decision has been given: Rev. Father Halter says he does not know of these instructions, and that he has always been guided by letters written by Mr. Leyter Reed, and the Hon. David Laird, Commissioners, Dept. of Indian Affairs, and by the Hon. Clifford Sifton, Minister of the Interior. I am enclosing herewith copies of these letters, handed to me by the Principal for the purpose. I informed him that your letter stated the regulations are, that cases such as these should be discussed with the Indian Agent, and submitted to the Department before accepting the children into the School. His comment was: "These children were brought and left here by the parents."

On my return to Edmonton, I called on His Grace, Archbishop J. H. MacDonald, at his residence. Our interview was short. I gave him a history of the case, as stated above. I understood him to say that he would take the matter up with Ottawa direct.

If Allan is sent back from Blue Quills School to his home on the reserve, I think that his chances of being given some education will be lost to him, and through no fault of his own. After reading what Agent Gullion has written about the case, I do not think the parents will consider at all the question of sending him to the Edmonton School, having signed the application to admit him to Blue Quills School, where he has been in attendance since April, 1940, and insisting that he be admitted.

As regards the per capita grant: The Principal says that this does not enter into the matter at all. He has other Treaty Indian children from the reserves, who are eligible as grant-earning pupils, for whom he is not paid, because the Department will not increase the quota of grant-earners for his School.

The girl, Annie, will not return after the Summer holidays, as she will be sixteen (16) years of age.

The Principal also states that the Hunters have told him that if John's health continues to improve as it is now doing, they want to place him in Blue Quills School in September, next.

From what I can understand of this case, I think it is one which should be decided on the grounds of Natural Law: It does not appear that the Hunter's have any strong dislike for the Edmonton School or anyone there. They desire and ask to have their children educated in the Blue Quills School. As regards the question of Creed: Their remarks and actions must be some proof of what they think and believe.

Your obedient servant,

G. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo with reference to the request for the admission of three children of Norman Hunter to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letter and I feel that it is advisable for you to again point out to the Principal that the circular letters to which he refers cannot, at the present time, be considered the policy of the Department. You should remind him that whenever there is any doubt regarding the eligibility of a child for admission to a residential school, either on religious or other grounds, such child must not be accepted by a Principal of a residential school until all the facts in the case have been placed before this Department and our decision has been given. I have reviewed the letters to which you refer and I find that when the Hunter children were placed in the Edmonton Residential School the father refused to sign the application forms. It would, therefore, appear that the father has not at any time been favourably disposed to their admission to the Edmonton School.

It has been decided to approve the admission of three children to the Blue Quills School provided the father makes formal application for their admission, using the usual application form for this purpose. We have received an application

Calgary, Alta.
from the father for Allain Hunter but we have not yet received any applications for Annie and John Hunter. The necessary forms for the latter two children should be forwarded for our consideration.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

re Allan Hunter No.308-
Blue Quills School-

In reply to your letter of the 21st ultimo, upon perusing the school file I find that the application for the above child was forwarded to the department by Agent Gullion on Nov. 25th 1940, duly signed by the father Norman Hunter. Letter No.118-1-10, dated Dec.6th 1941 acknowledged this application but refused admission of the boy to the school. Then followed a number of letters dealing with this case of which your office is aware. Witness your letter 407-11A R.C., April 9th 1941, addressed to Acting Agent Booree. The dept's letter was in error in stating that they had not received the application, reference letter No. 118-1-10. Copy attached.

Annie Hunter was duly admitted by dept's letter No.118-1-10, dated May 28th 1941.

John Hunter was not admitted owing to this boy being sick and he did not attend the Blue Quills School.

The Principal of the Blue Quills School forwarded me a copy of his letter to you dated July 25th 1941. It would appear that the department should be able to recover from their files the original application in connection with Allan Hunter #308.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

"We have received an application from the Father for Allan Hunter but we have not yet received any application for Annie and John Hunter. Dear Sir,

re Wilbert Gladu.

With reference to the enclosed application for the above pupil to the Blue Quill's Indian School, I beg to report as follows:

This pupil is the son of Vera Desjarlais, nee Lindstrom, now married to George Gladue, son of Pierre Gladue No. 32 Beaver Lake Band. George is a young Indian 19 years of age and married this widow shortly after treaty, about the beginning of July this year; it would appear that this woman had three children:

- Benny, Age 14
- Wilbert, Age 10
- Willie, Age 3

This woman resided in Lac La Biche and was getting a widow's pension in the sum of $30.00 per month, however apparently love called. The boy Benny is now in the Alberta Provincial Reformatory, having been sentenced there for stealing in the village of Lac La Biche. Wilbert was living with his grandmother in Lac La Biche but I understand for the last two months has been living on the reserve with his mother likewise the youngest Willie.

What is the position of these children? The couple went thru a legal marriage being performed by a R.C.Priest.

For your information I advised this boy against this marriage as also, did a number of other persons.

Kindly advise me of your ruling in regards to these children, if they will be admitted to Treaty or not, also as to the Application for admission.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of November 1941.

SCHOOL

Visited the Blue Quill's School on Nov. 25th and 26th. This school is quarantined for a mild outbreak of chicken pox. Attached my school report, I am experiencing a little difficulty in getting the information accurate from Father Balter, but will have this straightened out in the New Year. There have been 12 runaways (boys) from this school during November, I think this is due to changes of staff at the school. They appear boys to have settled down now. There are still two boys missing, these boys are over age. The School building programme is now closed for the season, the new building being roofed and sides closed in.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant with reference to Wilbert Gladu.

As pointed out in official letter of the 3rd instant, the Gladu children are not considered wards of this Department and consequently not eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils to any Indian residential school. With regard to the Principal's request to keep the boy, even though grant is not paid, I regret that such procedure cannot be approved. As you are aware, Indian residential schools are operated for the education of Indian children only and if we allowed others to be kept in the school, even though grant is not paid for them, very many difficulties would be encountered within a short time.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform the department that the father of the above two pupils has enlisted, up to the time of writing I have not been advised in what unit. The father No.91 Blue Quill's Band, Alex Doghead, enlisted I understand under the name of Alex Cardinal (also a family name) married an outsider by the name of Mary LaRose last winter, his wife is now staying with her parents at Vilna, Alberta together with her step children. Doghead stated to me that it was his desire that his two children under the circumstances should stay with his wife and go to a public school. I informed him that I was not sure of the position of the allowances of these children and I would refer the case to the department.

For your information Doghead is of the "smart-Alex" type of Indian and did not live on the reserve for the last couple of years.

The children are supposed to be attending Castle Park School. The children are attending school under the tax payment of their father-in-law Edward LaRose, Vilna, Alberta.

I would ask the department's ruling in the matter.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
October 28, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to the Cardinal children. I am inclined to feel that the only reason the children are residing with their stepmother is in the hope that she will be able to draw separation allowance for them. Taking everything into consideration I believe that it would be in the best interests of these children to return to the Blue Quills School. They were regularly admitted to that school on application forms signed by the father and presumably were only allowed out of the Blue Quills Residential School for summer holidays. They should have been returned upon the expiry of their leave. You should, therefore, make the necessary arrangements to have them returned to the Blue Quills School at once.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I herewith enclose three applications for admission to the Blue Quills Indian School, St. Paul, Alberta and wish to comments as follows:

re Delia Elizabeth Cardinal.

When I asked the parents for the signing of this application the mother stated she did not want to sign the application until she saw how the child's knee progressed during the child's attendance at school. The mother was in no way antagonistic about the matter, and this child under the circumstance I think would be well admitted as a grant earning pupil.

Olivine Matosek and Annie Matosek Aged 5½ and 3½ years.

The mother of these two children has been in hospital since October 5th last and still is. In talking to the Doctor today he was not sure how long she would be in but stated that she was improving in health. The father made the request that his two children be placed in school, at the present time the father is off the reserve working out. The Principal of the Blue Quills School is willing to accept these two children.

Respectfully submitted,

Ottawa, January 28, 1943.

Mr. W.P.B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, you may inform the Principal of the Blue Quills Residential School that the Department approves the discharge of pupils numbered as follows:

Numbers 238; 253; 262; 265; 277;
278; 292; 312; 0285; 0310;
0311.

The admission of Robert Cardinal to the Blue Quills School is also approved.

On the December quarter return there are shown the names of 89 pupils none of whom were present in the school during that quarter. I presume that, in the majority of cases at least, these pupils were allowed home on holidays and did not return upon the expiry of their leave. As a result, they are losing the advantage of their education and the school management is suffering a rather heavy financial loss. I would appreciate your advising what action you have taken to assist the Principal in having these children returned to the school. I know you will agree with me that it is most important that they should be returned at the earliest possible date.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

With reference to your letter of January 25th last and to the last paragraph in regards to the 29 pupils absent from the Blue Quill's Indian School. For your information I attach hereto a break down of the pupils absent from this Agency and Onion Lake Agency. The break down is self explanatory.

For your information the return of the pupils was most difficult last fall, what with the various families away harvesting when school opened and then the very early heavy snow fall on Nov. 12th which tied up nearly all traffic, except horses—this also made the contacting of the absent pupils very difficult. However most of the pupils have now returned from this Agency. It is my intention to be more severe in the return of the pupils another fall. This last fall what with the rumors of days schools and the very heavy harvesting which was not completed before winter, it was just one difficult job to get all the children back. Now going the rounds is the rumor that the Americans are buying both Blue Quill's and the Edmonton School. It is very difficult to disperse the unrest that these rumor cause among the illiterate Indians.

I might say that the education of the Indian children in this Agency has been badly neglected. There has been 18 new recruits from this Agency to Blue Quill's School this term. Any comments and suggestion that the department may make will be much appreciated.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

I would ask that this letter also be taken as a further report to my letter File 95-dated Oct. 20th 1942—in reply to Dept's File 110-1-10 dated Aug. 17th 1942.

I have again written their teacher and asked for a report up to date, which I will inform the dept. of. REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1943.

BLUE QUILL'S SCHOOL.

Reach for the asprin - 6 boys ran away on from this school on March 7th during severe weather 15 below zero - one froze his feet very badly and will lose some toes and part of one foot. The father did not take this boy to hospital when ordered to do so, but waited four days. This is the subject of an enquiry and a report will be submitted. Four boys again ran away on the 21st March, but have been returned. Two are still out of school from the first runaway of six; brothers of the Clarence Cardinal who had his feet frozen.

I inspected the school March 19th - there had been an outbreak of flu. School Report (herewith) will be forwarded.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
